She sits in my garden and says, "You are lucky to have a holiday." I feel sad about the empty days of summer. I think about walking to the shops and sitting alone in the park. 
"Tomorrow, I will go to Stonebridge. Can you feed my cats?" I ask Jaz. "Yes, I will," she replies. "Where will you stay?" she asks. "I will stay with my friend Ruby," I say. This is not true, but I often tell stories.
Jaz asks about her story, "The Cruelty of Red Vans." I like the title. I think red vans can be mean because they bring gifts to other people. I want to give Jaz some advice. "Try writing about nice people," I say. She looks upset. "I write in my journal about good things every day," I tell her. 
"Keep a journal? Get a life, Ann," she replies. I have a life. I work, and I go out sometimes. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calm. Then I remember my old teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who used to wink at us and say, "I've had my moments." We all laughed. 
---
**Questions:**
1. Why did the person choose this place to live?
2. What does the person usually do at home?
3. Who is Jaz?
4. What does Jaz bring down from her apartment?
5. What does the person think about summer?
6. Where is the person going tomorrow?
7. What is the title of Jaz's story?
8. What advice does the person give to Jaz?

**Heritage**
Heritage means the things we get from our past. It helps people feel connected to their history. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. Learning about our past helps us understand our future. Heritage is important because it gives us a sense of belonging. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit our culture from our families. Some parts of our heritage may not be good, but it is still a part of us. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our happiness. It includes our customs and the things we make. In the past, we learned about our history through stories from our ancestors. But now, many of these stories are lost. We can learn about our past from old buildings and places. It is important to take care of these places to remember our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I wrote a book called *Waterland*. In this book, I talk about a place in England called the Fens. At first, I did not know much about the Fens. I chose this place because it seemed quiet and simple. But when I learned more, I found that the Fens are very interesting and different. Many people in England think the Fens are strange. They are both empty and full of life, and they are beautiful in their own way. I have not visited some towns in the Fens, but I like to imagine what they are like. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, museums just put things in glass cases with long labels. Now, museums should be more interesting and fun. They can use different ways to show their items and make people feel something. Museums should help everyone in the community. For example, they can give boxes of objects to teachers or help elderly people who forget things. Museums show real items from history, not copies. This is what makes them special. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will attract more visitors who want to see real history.
**Architecture and Environment**
Wanting to keep things safe is not new. But now, changes in our towns happen very fast. This can make some people want to protect old buildings. People who have lived through big events, like wars, may want to keep things stable. If we need to preserve our history, city planners should think about this. Change can be good if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

Einstein**
If you stop someone on the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used to sell many things, like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did. They know he made important ideas called 'relativity'. These ideas can be hard to understand and seem strange.
Einstein helped change how we think about science. He looked at basic things like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people thought that stars and planets moved in a fixed way. Einstein said that time and space are not fixed; they can change.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, my sister Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books. We thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this and often told us to read better books. Our father gave us small coins to read good books. He also gave us some books for Christmas and birthdays that he said were not boring. We thought many of his books were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and poems.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the start of human language is a secret and wonderful thing. Many people have strange ideas about how language began. For example, Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans made sounds when they were in danger, and some words today still show this, like "malaria" meaning "fever" and "mors" in Latin meaning "death".
Many people did not want to talk about how language started because they thought it was silly. But now, studying how language began is very important. Language likely started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech to be friendly and to help in fights. Sharing information was not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said.

Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode talks about writing reviews. A review is a short piece of writing that gives an opinion about a book, movie, or other work. Most reviews are written quickly and are not read for long. They are often in newspapers or magazines and may only be read for a day or a week.
Many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Some writers do it because they need money. Others do it because they cannot spend all their time on a big project like a novel. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review of 600 or 800 words than to write a longer one of 6,000 or 8,000 words. 
A reviewer must think about who will read the review. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want more details. A good reviewer knows a lot about different topics and can write in a way that is easy to understand.
Many reviewers also write other things, like books or articles. For example, the American writer John Updike writes novels but also writes reviews. He collects his reviews in books with funny titles.
Some people think that writing reviews is not as good as writing serious books. But in English-speaking countries, many writers do both. It is now common for professors to write reviews, and this is accepted more than before. 
Writing reviews can be good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them remember to write clearly for everyone, not just for other professors. 
In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a side job. You can do it well only if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. It was dark and quiet inside. Sometimes, after three years, he still felt a little strange when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come back. He wondered what the flat had been doing while he was away. It felt like a welcome place for him, a space that was always there for him. 
He thought he should worry about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat was always waiting for him. It looked either clean or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as part of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He got frustrated that he could not change it. 
Sometimes, letters piled up by the door, and the answering machine blinked when he got home. He was happy that his windows were not broken and that nothing bad had happened to his flat. From his small office, Ralph often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After a long day at work, he wanted to be alone, but he also felt lonely. 
At his desk, he wanted to be by himself, but when he got home, he felt empty. He thought that his job was not right for him and that it changed him. He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. 
There was a time when he felt stronger and believed in himself. He wanted to improve his life, but he just wanted to get by. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, following them as they moved forward. He went to one job interview and was happy to talk with Neil, his future boss. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who applied. Ralph took this as a compliment.

**Goat Racing**
I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many people, ice-cream vans, and food stalls. The music was loud. Everyone was going to the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good place to watch. They made a special area for the race. It was not like a big racecourse, but people stood on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few goats in order. This is not easy because goats can eat almost anything!
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I thought about the night. I felt scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was no place to stop. We had not seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we saw the cliffs. Our flashlight was getting weak, so we changed the batteries, but they did not work. We could not find a place to camp. After a while, Lesley saw a light far away, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the waves. Soon, we heard loud water, but we could not see it. We kept moving.
**How to Be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a manager, I have to present to my colleagues and important people. How can I get better at this? You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many leaders need to do it well. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you say. Show your passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare. Think about your ideas carefully. Ask your colleagues what hard questions the audience might ask. You should also start with something people can relate to and then lead to your main point.

Some activities take time. You cannot hurry them. If you are late for a meeting, you can rush. But if you are too quick with mayonnaise, it will not be good. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very fast, but others take time. 
We can get better at some things, like solving puzzles. But some things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they will not work well. For example, you cannot sleep well in a short time. 
We learn and think in different ways. Some ways are fast, and some are slow. There are three speeds of thinking. The first speed is very fast. Sometimes, we need to react quickly. For example, if you fall off a bike, your body knows what to do before you think about it. 
The second speed is thinking. This is when we solve problems and make decisions. A mechanic fixing a car or a student doing homework is using this kind of thinking. We call this 'intellect'. 
The third speed is slow. This is when we think in a relaxed way. Sometimes, we need to sit and think about things slowly. This is important too. 
Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. For example, if you are not sure about something, it is good to take your time and think. This slow thinking can help us be creative and wise. 
Scientists are now studying how our minds work slowly. They find that our minds can do many important things if we give them time. They can understand complex situations better than quick thinking.

Living in a New Place**
I have been welcomed nicely. It is a friendly place with many people. There are about forty people here - scientists, students, and weather experts. We all help each other. My French is okay for talking, but not for chatting. I miss some words, and my phrasebook does not help at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt shy. I was a little scared at mealtimes. I did not know which table to sit at. I felt nervous when I spoke, like when I was new in school. I still smile a lot or feel scared when people talk to me. I think I feel a little sad because I cannot talk as easily as before.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was a young writer. He did not notice me. He remembered faces, and when I saw him, he shook my hand but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he did not see me. Then, I became a successful playwright, and Elliot started to be nicer to me. One day, he invited me to lunch. I thought he wanted to know me better. After my success, I saw him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
Alfred Hitchcock was a famous film director. He said he did not care about the story or the acting in his films. He cared about the pictures and the music. For Hitchcock, it was not about the message or the acting. He believed that people feel the same way when they watch a good film, no matter where they are from. If a film is made well, people in Japan and India should react the same way. Hitchcock was very smart and knew a lot about films. He wanted to make people feel strong emotions when they watched his movies. He focused on the beauty of film and how it can affect the audience.

Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and books. Telescopes were not very good. Now, there are many types of telescopes and equipment to buy. Computers help make charts and analyze observations. This is a good time for amateur astronomy.
But some things are not as good. Now, you may have to travel far to find a dark sky. In cities, the sky is not as clear as it was 50 years ago. There are many planes in the sky, and they leave trails that can last a long time. This makes it hard to see the sun and the stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are many things to do and many products to buy. People want the newest things, and technology makes this faster. New products come out all the time. This can make people feel tired and stressed. 
People are looking for simple things that make them happy in a complicated world. But it is not easy to simplify life when there are so many options. There are many brands of soap and cereal, and many phone plans. 
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, my family goes to McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother. It is very important to us. We do not want anything to change this tradition.
The guests at McAndrews Hotel are special. Some people may think they are old-fashioned. I do not like rude shop assistants or waiters who are too friendly. I know many of the other guests because we have been coming here since we were children. When I see them, we only say hello. This respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels today.

Othello and Lake Vostok**
**Othello**  
There is a play called Othello by Shakespeare. It is now in London. I wrote a bad review of it last spring. I said the actor Ray Fearon was too young for the role of Othello. I was wrong about his acting. He did a great job. The whole cast is great. There are many memorable scenes. One scene is when Cassio plays games with other young officers. It gets out of hand. Another scene is when Iago starts to lose control. It is very emotional when Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed. The play is exciting. You should see it.
**Lake Vostok**  
In Antarctica, there is a big lake called Lake Vostok. It is under 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been closed off from air and sunlight for 25 million years. Scientists want to explore this lake and find out what lives there. They are very excited to learn about it. Many researchers are trying to find ways to study the lake. In the next few years, we may learn a lot about Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. They want to know why we want to learn. It is important to understand what we do in science. We should think about how and why we use science.

**Food**
Food is very important to us. Many people who like cooking buy cookbooks. Sometimes, we think cooking is only for special days or fancy meals. But that is not true! You can make a tasty soup with just some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This soup is better than buying a packet or a tin. You can also make a yummy dessert in five minutes that everyone will enjoy. Cooking is a way to show care and love. Sharing food is special. We celebrate important days like birthdays and anniversaries with food. No one wants fast food for a wedding!
**In the Elevator**
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but it was still messy. Papers were everywhere. He had tax forms and many books. As he took the elevator to his floor, he thought about Mallory. She was always on time. She would knock on his office door exactly at the hour. Alistair worried about the mess. What would she think? He hoped she would not be too shocked. His cleaning lady, Mrs. Wilson, had come while he was trying to clean. When he saw her, he smiled, but she looked unhappy. She did not want to go into his messy office.
**Karen**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She made her own story. When she was twelve, her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she would go blind. But the doctor said she was okay. She only needed a few stitches. When she opened her eyes in the doctor’s office and saw her mother, she felt grateful. She knew she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty was happy and sad at the same time. She had just seen something important in her small village. She liked to be the first to know news, but she was also worried about Dr. Bailey. He had been her doctor for many years. He always cared for her when she was sick. Miss Fogerty appreciated how he listened to her problems. He made her feel like he had time for her. This is why everyone in the village liked him so much. He gave his time, knowledge, and humor to his patients. They loved him for it.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She plays music for many people. She also writes books for young children who want to learn the piano. 
Joanna plays the piano very well. She can play many types of music like classical, jazz, and blues. One time, at a concert for kids, a small boy asked her, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This made Joanna laugh. She thought it was funny that the boy wanted to hear that song. 
Joanna cares a lot about how children learn to play the piano. She has written a book called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World* for beginners. Even though she is very busy, she wants to help children learn music. 
Joanna believes that everyone should be able to learn the piano, just like swimming or speaking a little French. Some kids learn quickly, but others take more time. She thinks it is important for children to enjoy music, not just to be the best. 
Joanna wants her books to be fun. She includes stories in her books to make learning interesting. She also has CDs with music to help children play. She believes that learning should be fun and that children should practice. 
Joanna understands that practicing can be hard. She wants to help children enjoy playing the piano, even if they make mistakes. She thinks it is important to have a goal when practicing. 
In her view, everyone can learn to play music if they have fun and keep trying.

Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said, "What is easy to write is often not nice to read." This means good writing is hard to do. When I look at my old school essays, I see that I did not cross out many words. Now, I would change them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is hard. Writing slowly helps me think better. When I write on a computer, I can change things easily, but I often make mistakes. 
Emails are different from handwritten letters. Many people now write love letters by email. This is good because at least they are writing. But words on a screen can be boring. People often write too quickly and their messages can be confusing. Writing by hand is special and has more feeling.
One day, I looked at a CD. The case was not nice, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. Mr. Warriston came into the room and said, "These are wonderful!" I agreed and gave him the disc. He said, "It is amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on one." He turned on the music player and many lights turned on. He put the disc inside and pressed a button. 
I asked, "Do you have to turn it over like records?" He said, "No, you only play one side." I wondered why. He thought for a moment and said, "I don’t know. You could make both sides play." He smiled and said, "Good question!" Then he told me to sit in the best place to hear the music.
**Books vs. Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said that if we had cigarette lighters before matches, we would think lighters are amazing. Some people say that electronic text is as important as the invention of books. But this is not true. It takes a long time for people to change how they think. 
Reading long things on a screen is not nice for many people. Most people do not do it. Computers make it easy to read small parts of text, but they do not help us read everything from start to finish. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from beginning to end. 
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office. It was very neat. The carpet was clean and the desk was dark wood. Everything was in its place. Kathleen was trying to close a filing cabinet. She said, "You need to use computers, Charles. This is too much." 
"Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, looking at the room. He did not want to think about computers. They had talked about this many times. She did not understand why he did not like technology. He was good with computers and had even written an important paper about them. She could use software to create new things.

"Do you want sugar in your coffee?" shouted his secretary. She asked this because she had made coffee for Lancelot many times. She forgot because he was not usually at work. But now, he was there all the time. He thought about how he went from being an important helper to someone who was always busy and had no place to park.
"Here is something," she yelled, waving a folder. "It is from a man in Los Angeles. You wanted to see it." The folder had a label that said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one. Ian Cuthbert had received a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was a friend who Lancelot had asked to write books, but Ian was very hard to work with.
Lancelot quickly read the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and put it aside. It seemed like Ian's manuscript would never come. The synopsis did not have the great ideas that people said Ian had. Lancelot remembered a famous author who had published an incomplete book after he died. But that author had not received any money before. Ian had received a lot of money, which was not how things should work.
Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising writer. He had many ideas and was very talented. But for some reason, Ian did not share his ideas. While other writers became successful, Ian stayed quiet. He was hard to work with, even when he was in charge of a magazine. The magazine used a lot of money but never published anything. Ian also had a contract with a fashion magazine, but he did not produce anything there either. At meetings, he was often rude and critical of others' ideas. Now, Lancelot thought that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

England's Breakfast Change**
Breakfast is very important for health, say experts. But in the past, breakfast was not common in England. In old stories, people did not often talk about breakfast. Some travelers ate a meal early in the morning before long trips. Sick people sometimes had breakfast to feel better. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or rich people.
In the 1500s, more people started to eat breakfast. Some people think this happened because there was more food available. But there were also big changes in society. For example, more people had jobs with set hours. Many of these jobs started very early in the morning. So, eating breakfast became necessary for everyone, not just for rich people.

**Photography**
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show. This choice depends on their skills, ideas, and experiences. It also depends on the culture and society around them. In this book, we will see how these things change the style and meaning of a photograph. We will also see how people look at and feel about these pictures.
For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they understand the photos in it. But we can ask questions about the photos. Does the photo show what really happened? Or does it show what the photographer thinks? Is the moment in the photo very important, or does it mean something bigger about the world?
**More than a Game**
For me, sports are more than just a game. The best athletes believe in themselves completely. To be the best, you need to focus and work hard. Sports can be tough, and you must do it yourself. It is a challenge. 
Sports teach me discipline and determination. They also show me how to work with a team. My sport lets me shine as an individual, but it is also a team sport. This is like life – you can do well alone, but you must remember others are with you. Sports have given me a lot, not just money. They have opened doors for me and let me see many things in the world. But I also have to give up a lot to get these rewards.
**Tuning In**
Some memories are very clear and special. For me, one special memory is from a night in California a long time ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing in a tree. I was not awake because I could not sleep; I was awake because the bird sang beautifully. 
As I listened to the bird, I felt like I was in a special musical place. The bird's songs reminded me of jazz and Indian classical music. It felt like a wonderful performance. I enjoyed the music until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked a lot about birds. Birds are important in our culture. Paul Evans writes about this. 
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird is bumping against the glass. This bird is a wren. Some people think wrens are special and have messages for us. Others think it is just a bird that is lost. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, we still see pictures of wrens in many homes. Even if old beliefs are not common now, people still like wrens. A place without wrens feels sad. 
There are many stories about birds that show how people used to see the world. In the past, people depended on nature for food and safety. They learned to understand the meaning of birds in their lives. 
One example is the red kite bird. In the 1500s, people in London loved to see red kites flying down to get food from children. These birds were important and protected. But later, people thought they were pests and many were killed. Now, red kites are protected again and are coming back to their old homes. 
Birds are important to us for many reasons. They can show us things about nature and ourselves. Birds can fly, sing, and represent freedom. Some people think our feelings about birds are not important now, but they are still part of who we are. 
In recent years, birds have shown us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means we are losing not just birds, but also part of our culture. 
Some birds, like the skylark and turtle dove, are symbols of love and magic. Many poems and stories talk about these birds. When we lose these birds, we feel sad. But we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not in stories or poems. 
Stories about birds are very important. They connect us to the past and help us feel emotions. Watching birds, whether on TV or in our backyards, gives us joy that science cannot explain. The wren in the greenhouse reminds us of our history and makes us think about the future.

Maps**
A map shows where places are on the earth. It helps us understand how far things are and in what direction they are. Long ago, people talked about distance in time, like "a few hours' walk" or "a day's trip by river." This helped people know how easy it was to travel, not just how far it was.
For many travelers, the most important questions were "Where do I go?" and "How far is it?" So, exact directions were not always very important. Because of this, written directions were used a lot, just like maps. Some maps, like train maps, do not always show true directions.
In the past, important places were marked with signs. These signs could be big or small, depending on how important the place was. Different maps used different signs, so it is important to understand what each map means.
Over time, maps became more accurate. People learned to use tools like the compass to find directions. They also learned more about the earth through exploration. They found out that the earth is not a perfect ball; it is a bit flat at the poles. This helped make better maps.
More people started using maps, not just travelers. Soldiers needed maps to understand the land for battles. Later, archaeologists, historians, and geographers also needed maps for their work. Today, map makers create maps for many things, like weather and land use.
The study of maps is important because it shows us how people thought and worked in the past. Many maps we have today are the result of a lot of hard work and ideas. This is why learning about old maps is interesting and helpful.

I met a young man named Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a nice room with many records and a stereo. Andrew was a teenager who liked music. He won a scholarship to study history at a college in Oxford. He wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for fun, money, and fame. 
Andrew asked me to help him write songs. He played some of his music on the piano, and I thought it was very good. I showed him a song I had written with a small band. We decided to meet again and write music together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I thought Andrew was very talented.
The next day, I went back to my job as a lawyer. I thought about my dreams of being in show business with Andrew. I still looked for bands that needed a singer. I worried that I would stop liking pop music soon, as my father said I would. But I wanted to see Andrew again. It would be fun to write songs for musicals.
Andrew had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man who helped orphans. I thought the story was not very exciting, but Andrew believed in his music. I started to write funny songs for the musical. I even skipped work one day to write lyrics. I didn’t know it then, but I was starting a new career.

**Text:**
**Language**  
You and I can talk to each other. This is a special skill. We use language every day. When people are together, they talk. If no one is there, people talk to themselves, their dogs, or even their plants. I think talking is like an instinct. This means we know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather come from the air around us. They affect animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet places have tropical jungles with many types of plants and animals. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather changes every day because of moving air. The sun also helps to move the air.
**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, I served drinks and made coffee. In Melbourne, a restaurant needs good coffee. I had many days of training to learn how to make coffee. I learned how to clean the coffee machine and make a good cappuccino. At first, it was hard to make coffee. My boss was kind and said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science. You need time to learn."

Art on TV**
Why does television not show art well? Painting and sculpture are good for TV because the camera can show the whole artwork and also show the details. But there are not many TV shows that show the beauty and details of art. 
One example is Robert Hughes's show called "American Visions." He is a trusted critic and has a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British people American art, which British galleries do not show. I thought the show would focus on great artworks. Instead, it talked about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer and became known for taking risks. The metals market is not controlled as much as other markets. With some luck and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this job. 
But now, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep metal prices high have found that more minerals are being taken out of the ground, and prices are going down. After considering inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. Each island is different and has something special. To get around the islands, you need a boat. If you don’t get a boat with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to go by yourself. 
Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called "The Sailing Capital of the World" because the waters are calm and safe. It is also great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Build Your Own Bamboo Bike**
You can build your own bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This club is run by two engineers, James and Ian. They help you make a bike frame from bamboo. You can join a fun weekend course to learn how to build your bike.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, London. The Bamboo Bike Club is busy with people making bikes. Bamboo is a special material for making bike frames. Many people like bamboo bikes, but they can be very expensive. A ready-made bamboo bike frame can cost about $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes that everyone can afford. They worked hard to create a way for people to build their own bikes. They want to share the fun of making something special. The Bamboo Bike Club is a community project. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer.
In the course, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and how to put the pieces together. You will use tools and follow plans to build your bike. James and Ian help you with every step. If you make a mistake, it is okay! You can try again with a new piece of bamboo.
On the second day, you will work on the bike's details. You will wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. At the end, you will have a bike that is ready to ride. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are strong and last a long time.
The bamboo bikes look different from metal bikes. They have a unique style. Some people like to ride them slowly and enjoy the ride. The Bamboo Bike Club offers a great way to learn and have fun. The price for the course is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**  
Diane Reverend worked as an editor at Random House in New York. One day, she saw a book by a new author, Dr. John Gray. She thought the book would be very popular, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very rich, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand each other better. This book is part of a big self-help industry in America. Many people want to improve their lives, and this industry helps them. There are many self-help books, but many are not published because they are not good enough. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "Is the author interesting?" and "Does the title catch attention?" A good title can help a book sell better.
**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, they should tell the truth. But sometimes, writers do not tell everything. They may feel ashamed or think some things are not important. Sometimes, they make up stories to explain their lives better. They may call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. 
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
Dashiell Hammett wrote detective stories. These stories show problems in society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In these stories, a crime represents human feelings like greed or desire. Solving the crime helps society return to normal. In Hammett's stories, both the detective and the criminal understand each other. The detective is part of both worlds: he is a little bit good and a little bit bad. His job is complicated because he feels connected to both sides.
**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. He believes that only scientists can write well about science. If you do not understand science, it is hard to write about it. Gould says that writers should not talk down to their readers. They can use simple words, but they must keep the main ideas clear. If readers feel that the writer is treating them like they are not smart, they will not like the writing. 
---
**Questions:**
1. Who is Diane Reverend?
2. What did Dr. John Gray write about?
3. Why do some autobiographies not tell the whole truth?
4. What do Hammett's detective stories show about society?
5. What does Stephen Jay Gould say about writing science?

Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, it is cold inside. Many people from the City of London come here for lunch. This summer is very hot, so the gym uses a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels very cold, like the Arctic. This shows how we use air-conditioning too much. 
Air-conditioning is common in many buildings. But there are other ways to keep places cool. Buildings can use sunlight and fresh air. They can have thick walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A long time ago, they were very important for telling time. People needed them to keep their clocks right. But as clocks became better, sundials were not used much. They became pretty decorations in gardens.
Now, people are interested in sundials again. David Harber makes sundials. He thinks they are special because they connect us to the sun and planets. When he delivers a sundial, it feels magical when it starts to work. Sundials are calm and remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I remember seeing china-painting at an art show. Older women painted flowers on teacups very carefully. They made perfect petals and leaves. I thought it would be hard to paint like them. 
But when I went to a china-painting class, it was fun! The students were happy and wanted to enjoy painting. The teacher did not want everyone to paint like robots. It was a nice and friendly atmosphere.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, in a hotel called Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went to the travel agency to book the holiday, the clerk said they would be with a school group from the south coast. This group was learning Italian.
But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Switzerland, not Venice. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard older people talking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there was a mistake.
When they landed, a woman with glasses told them to stay together. They did not see anything about an overnight stop in the brochure. When they got off the coach, it was almost midnight. They were tired and did not ask about their beds. But the next morning, they found out they would stay in the hotel for their whole holiday. This made them worried.
Keith told the receptionist, "We were meant to be in Venice." The receptionist said he did not know that hotel. Dawne said the travel agency's name and described the man who booked their holiday. 
A woman named Mrs. Franks came to help. She was the same woman they saw at Gatwick. Dawne told her they were in the wrong hotel. Keith said they followed the girl with the yellow-and-red uniform. 
Mrs. Franks explained that there are many holidays with the same yellow-and-red labels. She said if they followed the wrong people, they could end up in the wrong place. Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. 
Mrs. Franks then left them. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. Dawne said Mrs. Franks seemed nice, but Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane.
An old man named Mr. Nottage spoke to them. He and his wife were happy and said they had a good sleep. Dawne said that was nice. Keith and Dawne left the hotel and did not talk about how funny it was that they were on a holiday with old people. They wanted a holiday away from older people, but Uncle had chosen this trip for them.

**HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON**
Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was. He was an explorer in Antarctica. In America, people are just starting to learn about him. The Wall Street Journal called him "an Antarctic explorer" who was not well known for a long time. Now, many Americans are excited to learn about Shackleton. There are new books and a big exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History. A film about his life is also being made.
Some American managers look up to Shackleton as a good example of leadership. They talk about his adventures and what they can learn from him. Shackleton was strong and smart. He had a special sleeping bag and a stove made from animal fat. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, thinks Shackleton is a great role model. He helps companies communicate better during problems.
Shackleton made a tough choice when he was very close to the South Pole. He turned back because he wanted to keep his men safe. This showed that he cared about their lives. In a crisis, people want a leader. Shackleton was not afraid to take responsibility. His ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice for nine months and was finally crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men to trust him and do their best.
Shackleton always planned carefully and kept his men informed. He was flexible and changed plans when needed. He believed that explorers need to be hopeful, strong, and patient. He showed his men how to work together. For example, when he saw a photographer without gloves, he gave him his own gloves. Shackleton cared for his team, even when they were very hungry.
Caroline Alexander, who wrote a book about Shackleton, says that people today want to hear stories of real heroes. Shackleton is a true hero who shows us the values we admire. 
---
**Questions:**
1. Who was Sir Ernest Shackleton?
2. What did Shackleton do in Antarctica?
3. Why are Americans interested in Shackleton now?
4. What did Jim MacGregor think about Shackleton?
5. What important decision did Shackleton make near the South Pole?
6. How did Shackleton show he cared for his team?

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is a type of primate. It has a way of finding food that is similar to a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its big teeth to make holes and its long finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied the aye-aye to understand how it finds food. Dr. Carl Erickson watched three aye-ayes: two males named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects by looking for holes in the wood. Dr. Erickson made logs with holes. Some holes had food inside, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food. They did not need to see the holes to find the food.
Dr. Erickson thought the aye-ayes might find food by smell or sound, but they could find food even when there was no smell or sound. He found that the aye-ayes could feel the empty spaces in the wood. When they look for food, they tap the wood with their long finger and listen carefully. They can hear if there is a hollow space inside the wood.
The aye-aye is special because it can do things like a woodpecker and a bat. It also acts like a squirrel. Its teeth keep growing like a squirrel's teeth. Recently, scientists saw the aye-aye eating nuts in the wild. It used its long finger to get the nut meat out of the shell. 
**Questions:**
1. Where does the aye-aye live?
2. What does the aye-aye use to find food?
3. Who studied the aye-ayes?
4. What are the names of the aye-ayes that Dr. Erickson studied?
5. How does the aye-aye find food in the wood?

'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents. But how many of us know what their lives were like? We have some stories from our families, but they are often not complete. What will our grandchildren know about us? We want to write things down, but we often do not do it. 
Hannah Renier has a solution. She writes life stories for other people. She makes a book with at least 20,000 words and pictures if needed. She writes about ordinary people, not famous ones. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family. She saw that many stories from the past were disappearing. 
"When I started, I did not think it was very important," she says. "But then I met people who have interesting lives. They want to share their stories for their children and for the future. They enjoy it too." 
People feel safe to share their stories with Hannah. A 62-year-old man said, "I was honest. I talked about my divorce and it still hurts." He wrote his story for his family, but he has not let his children read it yet. He wants to protect them from some painful details. 
Hannah sees that many people are affected by their childhood. "Many people repeat the same mistakes in their lives," she says. "They marry people their parents liked or they choose the opposite to rebel." 
Many people have regrets. Even after many years, they still feel sad about things that happened with their parents. They try to impress their parents, but it does not always work. 
Hannah listens to people without judging them. "I am not here to be nosy," she says. People sometimes share things and then worry if it should be in the book. But most people want to be honest. 
Hannah's books are not for everyone. They are not about showing off. She believes we are losing our connection to the past. We need to remember our roots. 
Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these talks to write the life story. She can make the book look nice, and people can choose the color and title. The books are special and cost about £3,000. Extra copies cost £25 each. 
Hannah gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from buying. "I thought more people would want this," she says. "But the people I have worked with are often wealthy and want to leave something for their families."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces. Remember, these are not real sculptures. They are copies made from the originals, mostly made in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The Museum has a special gallery with good light. The copies are useful because you can see many sculptures together, even if the real ones are in different museums. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has darkrooms and a gallery for photography shows. We have courses and workshops for everyone, including a Beginner's Course and special classes with guest photographers. Members can use the darkrooms. We also help young photographers, aged 12 to 16, to learn with our Young Members scheme. We sell photography books and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a large collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward. There are nearly 10,000 interesting pieces in old cabinets. Adam Sedgwick was a professor and helped to grow the collection. The collection is organized by age, so you can see how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery shows beautiful minerals and gems, with labels to explain them.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
There are over 400,000 air photographs in this collection. They were taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft and takes photos all over Great Britain. The photographs show the landscape and how it has changed from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can buy copies, which take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest places for brass rubbing in the world. You can have fun making wall hangings by rubbing over one of the many brass plates from tombs of knights and ladies. The centre makes copies of the originals so that you can enjoy brass rubbing. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed in history, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Being a Parent**
A. **The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange life, but I love being a father. I have spent 35 years with my children, and I enjoy every moment. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I am very lucky with my children. We all like the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This makes us close. Now that they are older, I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have been angry and slapped them, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the best father, but I always try to be there for them. I wait for them to call me. I do not want to make them feel guilty if they do not call.
B. **The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, only 25 years old. I found being a parent hard sometimes, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new things like music and fashion. This helped me in my job. I missed some important moments when they were young, like their first concerts, and I feel sad about that. But now, I can take them on holidays, and they enjoy being with my friends at parties.
C. **The Politician**  
My first child was born when I started my political career. I promised my wife that we would spend time with our children, but it is hard because I am very busy. I only go to meetings on weekends if my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do, and they do not feel like I am gone all the time. I see more politicians bringing their kids to work. Maybe we all want our children to be part of our lives.
D. **The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I wanted to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated them like adults too soon. Kate thinks I was too easy on them. I wish I had set more rules. I still worry about my daughters, no matter how old they are.
E. **The TV Presenter**  
I was ready to be a parent when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home. We thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, made me think about who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but when I see her smile, all my worries go away. A baby's smile is very powerful.

When Emma is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is locked in a dark cellar. This book shows family life, friendship, and that adults are not always safe.

Mary Dyer feels different from her family. She loves her father’s racing pigeons. When her father goes away for work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes. This story is set in 1930 and teaches that there are many kinds of smartness.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
Rose is a woman who wants to escape her busy life. She moves to a cottage with her two children. A scary cat and strange things in the house show why the last owner, Yaxley, is gone. The locals do not like them, and they feel unsafe. The story is exciting and keeps you interested.

**Flying Without Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford writes about students who fly in a special plane to test their ideas. The plane looks like a normal airplane. It is a Boeing KC-135, made in 1964. But inside, it is very different. The inside is a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights. Most of the seats are gone, and 13 students from Europe and America sit at the back. They are excited but a little scared.
For one year, these students worked hard to win a chance to fly. The European Space Agency asked them to think of fun experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, which is like a big roller coaster.
During the flight, the plane goes up high and then down quickly. When it goes down, everything inside the plane becomes weightless for a few seconds. The students feel like they are floating. At first, the flight is smooth, but then the pilot makes the plane climb steeply. The students feel the pressure in their heads, and some fall on the floor.
When the plane goes down, they float in the air. They can jump and move easily. Up and down do not mean the same thing anymore. After a few seconds, the plane comes back down, and gravity returns. Some students land hard on the floor.
The students have 10 minutes of weightlessness to do their experiments. The Dutch students study their robot cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. They let their robot float and try to turn it over. 
Another group from Germany studies how metal joins change without gravity. A team from Utah State University tries to make solar sails from thin films in the air. They want to use the sun's energy like a sailboat uses the wind.
After two hours of flying, the students feel excited. One student says, "It was an unforgettable experience. I want to be an astronaut even more now."

Jonathon Porritt is a writer. He wrote a book called "Seeing Green." 
When he was younger, he spent many summers in New Zealand. But in New Zealand, it was winter. He liked winter. His parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for him and his siblings. They could plant trees there. His mother said, "If you plant trees, you can have the land." 
They found land near Auckland, in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was good for trees. Jonathon liked working with land. He had worked in Australia on farms. He thought planting trees was a nice idea. 
In 1968, he started planting trees. By 1972, he and his siblings had planted 70 acres of trees. In 1968, it rained a lot while they were planting. It was cold and wet, but Jonathon was happy. 
Every morning, he got ready to plant trees. He had a bag for trees. When the bag was full, it was heavy. It was easier when the bag was lighter. He had to make straight lines to plant the trees. He used poles to help him. 
Jonathon liked hard work. It made him strong. After a while, he could plant trees easily. He learned a rhythm for planting. He took the tree from the bag, dug a hole, put the tree in, and moved on. 
While planting, he thought a lot about life and nature. He went back to New Zealand four times and saw the trees grow. He felt good about the trees he planted. 
He worried when he read bad news about New Zealand, like strong winds or droughts. But the trees grew well, and they are now 20 years old. 
In 1984, he took time off from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. He wrote his first book there. He stayed in a simple cabin with a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, he wrote. In the afternoons, he took care of the trees. 
Jonathon feels a strong connection to that place. He believes it is important to connect people with the earth.

'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**
One day, I saw a helper bring a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have a farm in Somerset. We help orphaned animals. I heard strange noises from the box. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs. They were about eight inches long. They had soft fur and looked up at me with their milky eyes.
I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born in winter and stay underground. If their mother is not there, they can die. These three cubs were found by builders. The builders accidentally hurt their home. The mother was dead, but the babies were alive.
I took the cubs to my kitchen to keep them warm. There were two girls named Primrose and Bluebell, and one boy named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe. I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to help them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around.
Three weeks later, I saw that Willow was not active. He was still eating, but something was wrong. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. It was my fault because I let him drink too fast. I was sad, but I took care of the other two cubs.
Then, a farmer came to me. He found another badger cub, a boy, who was alone. I named him Willow II. He was younger than Primrose and Bluebell. He was hard to feed. I had to help him drink from the bottle. After a week, he learned to eat sausages.
By five months old, all the cubs were eating different foods. They liked cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, and nuts. Badgers usually eat worms, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were doing well, even in the hot summer.
By August, the badgers started to go out at night. They liked to play in the orchard. They chased each other and had fun. I learned to be careful when they played, but Derek sometimes got nipped.
One night, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food. Badgers can be dangerous to each other, so we put metal over the gate to keep them safe. The local newspaper took pictures of me with the badgers. Many people wanted to help build a home for them.
We made plans for a new home with tunnels and a special gate. It took a lot of money, but local businesses helped us. Finally, the badgers moved into their new home. I watched them and then left them alone. Later, I saw them sleeping in their chambers.
Now, I don’t walk with them as much because they wake up late. Primrose has moved to another home, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before they run off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy.

In Search of True North**
Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. He also did important work with compasses. He used his sea trips on a warship called Paramore to study the angle between magnetic north and true north. This angle is important for sailors to find their way on the ocean.
Halley wanted to chart this angle in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip to the Cape Verde Islands did not work out because of problems with the crew. But he tried again. On his second trip, he went to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a chart showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This chart helped sailors for many years.
Now, Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip. He plans to follow Halley's route. He needs to raise £70,000 to start this journey. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is helping him.
Dr. Clark learned about Halley while he was in Antarctica. He read many books about Halley. Dr. Clark says, "Halley had a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led many expeditions. He studied stars and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his work."
Dr. Clark wants to recreate Halley's voyage. He will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. The Earth's magnetic field changes slowly, so these measurements are important. Dr. Clark says, "We can use satellites to find true north."
The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will help with instruments. A Danish satellite will also take measurements. Dr. Clark hopes his work will help scientists understand the Atlantic Ocean better.
Halley's journey was the first scientific trip at sea. He was the first civilian to be a naval captain for this kind of work. Dr. Clark has experience too. He spent two years in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England.
He plans to complete the expedition in four parts with different crews. Dr. Clark says, "I am ready to spend eight months on this journey. Some people may think I am obsessed, but Halley’s life gives me a purpose."

**PEACOCKS IN WHIPSNADE PARK**
Every summer, peacocks walk around Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire. They show their beautiful feathers to the peahens. This is a mystery that Charles Darwin thought about a lot. He wondered why birds have such big and colorful tails. How do they survive with these big tails?
A scientist named Marion Petrie and her team are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade. Darwin said that animals change over time through evolution. He believed that the strongest animals survive and have babies. But he thought that peacocks' tails were not useful for survival. He called this idea "sexual selection." This means that female birds like beautiful males.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if peahens liked the males with the biggest tails, then those males must have something special that helps them survive. 
Now, 100 years later, scientists still want to know if peahens really choose the males with the biggest tails. They also want to find out if these males are better in other ways. At Whipsnade, the peacocks show off their tails in groups, and the peahens choose their favorites. 
Scientists have noticed that peahens like the males with the most eye spots on their tails. These males attract more mates. But they are still studying if these males are better in other ways. 
One scientist, William Hamilton, thinks that male birds with big tails might be healthier and have fewer parasites. This means they are less likely to be sick. Dr. Petrie is comparing the babies of attractive males with those of less attractive males. She wants to see if the babies of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier.
There is also an interesting idea from a scientist named R A Fisher. He said that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will have long tails, and their daughters will like long tails too. This could make the tails even longer over time. 
In the end, this means that females might choose males just for their beauty, as Darwin thought.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe says the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He made his own boat called 'The Westerman'. This week, there is a big boat show in London with many new yachts. Most of these boats have new technology and designs from 25 years ago. 
My boat is different. It is quiet and sits in a small creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic person because of this. I like old boat designs, but I also use some modern technology to help me. 
Modern technology is useful, but it can make sailing too easy. Sailors want to feel the real sea life, not just sit back and relax. I think it is important to have a warm stove and comfortable beds on a boat. But if everything is automatic, what is the fun in sailing? Sometimes, dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor. 
When I bought my first boat, Hirta, I sailed around Britain for a TV show. The last owner said it was comfortable but not luxurious. Hirta had heavy sails and no electricity, no fridge, and no fancy gadgets, but she was easy to sail. 
However, old boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing Hirta. I looked for a newer boat but could not find one, so I decided to build a new boat. 
The Westerman has been great. The designer, Nigel Irens, started drawing the boat on a paper napkin before using a computer. We made many changes to get the design just right. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. 
The Westerman looks beautiful and sails well. It is made from wood and is very strong against water. It feels like a real boat, not just a fancy one. I believe that a boat should be made for sailing, not just for comfort. Sometimes, it is good to learn from the past.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

**NATURAL TALENTS**
Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We share more than 98% of our genes. This means that we are not very different from them. Scientists study animals to understand what makes us human. They find that many things we thought were only human are also seen in animals.
For example, both humans and chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and to fight. Sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple way to communicate. They make different sounds for animals like leopards, eagles, and snakes. This shows that the differences between humans and animals are not very big.
Art is one thing that many people think is only human. But for a long time, our ancestors did not make art. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we do not have proof of this. The first clear evidence of human art is from about 35,000 years ago. This includes cave paintings, statues, and musical instruments.
Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways:
1. Human art is not made to help us survive. It is made for enjoyment. Animal behaviors, like birds singing, help them find mates or protect their homes.
   
2. Human art is made for beauty. We do not know if animals enjoy their songs. Birds sing mostly during mating season, so they may not sing just for fun.
3. Human art is learned. Each culture has its own art style. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. Animals, like some birds, are born knowing how to sing their songs.
There are also some interesting examples of animal art. Two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, made many paintings. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day. They did not make these paintings to communicate with other chimps; they did it for fun. Their paintings were shown in a gallery in London, and many people bought them.
This shows that the line between human art and animal behavior is not very clear. While human artists often want to share their art with others, some animal artists do not care about sharing at all.

A Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a very big and dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left today. In the past, stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes looking into the distance. Now, we do not see these heroes in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Charles Blackmore led a group across the Taklamakan Desert. The desert is very hard to cross. Its name means "once you enter, you never come out," and local people call it the Desert of Death. Charles talked about the dangers and excitement of his journey at home with his family. 
His team had four British people, one American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for everyone. 
They set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He wanted to have fun and find out who he really was. His wife, Tina, was worried he would not come back because no one had crossed that route before. 
It took them 59 days to cross the desert. Charles said the desert was "kind" to them, but they faced many problems. They had sickness, very hot and cold weather, and not enough water. They lost some of their water supply. But when they were very thirsty, they found water. They did not have the big sandstorms that the desert is known for, and they did not feel the very cold weather.
Charles said, "What pushed me on was the need to survive." They had no backup plan. They were alone in the desert. He was scared but knew he could do it. On the first day, it was very hot, and he thought, "We have to start now!" 
After walking for 1,000 kilometers, they could not stop. They were very thin but strong. Charles felt proud of crossing the desert. He thought about his family while lying in the desert at night, looking at the moon. He said, "I feel prouder of this trip than anything else." But he also thought about his family and their happiness.
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? He said, "I want the challenge and the open spaces. I find it hard to live in the same way as everyone else today."

Susan Harr is tired of technology. She decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. But Susan thinks that we depend too much on it. 
One day, her computer broke. It cost a lot of money to fix it. This made her think that gadgets are not always worth it. She started to stop using some of her household gadgets. She wonders if technology really gives us more time. 
When her gadgets make strange noises, she puts them outside. Now, she can take her time and enjoy sewing by hand. She feels safer without machines that can hurt her fingers. She can also take her sewing with her wherever she goes. 
Susan knows that some gadgets are useful, like the washing machine. But she found joy in not watching too much TV. She returned her color TV and now has a small black-and-white one. This helps her spend more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family. 
She used to think sewing by hand was hard and boring. But now, she enjoys it. She can listen to the radio or talk to friends while she sews. It feels nice to sit by the fire with a cup of tea and sew. 
Susan realizes that doing things by hand can be relaxing. She feels happy when she sees her work getting better. She also likes that she can take her time and not rush. 
Now, she thinks about what gadgets she really needs. Does she need a freezer or a microwave? Maybe she can save money by not using so many electric things!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles seems to be a busy man. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" 
His workshop is under a railway. It is full of furniture pieces and wood in many colors. Charles has been a cabinet-maker for ten years. He is well-known for his work. Many people want to buy his furniture, so he has many orders. He does not advertise himself, but people know he makes good cupboards, tables, and bookcases.
It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is hard to find a good one. Charles says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now." He is not happy with some furniture made today. He thinks some furniture is not good quality. He wants to make perfect furniture, and this is why he is successful.
Charles is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions. Most of his work is for private people. Some clients come back to him many times. He enjoys making furniture for their whole house.
Sometimes, working with clients is not easy. He finds it hard when clients do not know what they want. He likes clients who know what they want. Charles is happy with his work, but he also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me."
He does not like when craftsmen take a long time to make one piece of furniture. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just for show. Charles is confident, but he is also humble. He says, "After all, I am only making furniture," as I leave.
