Three Theories About Sleep**
People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but we do not know exactly why. Scientists have three main ideas about why we sleep.
The first idea is that sleep helps our bodies stay healthy. When we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us remember things we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things.
The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day.
These are the three main ideas about why we sleep.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, someone might love to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics.
Eccentricity shows our individuality. Inside us, there is a struggle between two things: wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in with others. Most people want to be accepted and liked. This desire is often stronger than the wish to be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and hold meetings to talk about what they like or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think they are strange.
We all feel a mix of wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. Sometimes, we want to show our individuality. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think." Or a new person might say, "You must take me as I am."
Anyone can choose to be more individual. Some people become very successful by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you know what you want to do, go for it and don’t give up. You will surprise many people." 
However, being different just to get attention is not true eccentricity. For example, if a singer wears strange clothes just to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they keep being different for a long time, they may become eccentric.
True eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to tell us about their favorite wildlife book. 
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward. She is a small, thin woman, but she is very important for environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences into her own ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand everything. Choosing the book was harder. I could choose "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think Barbara's most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes in her life. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of seagulls and remember the smell of the sun. This book explains the amazing world of animal communication with words and pictures. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a group of seagulls, you will see how they work together. Niko Tinbergen was a great scientist who wanted to share his ideas with everyone. He worked with a talented wildlife artist, Eric Ennion, to make this book interesting for all nature lovers. Eric's paintings show how birds act, like when one bird is aggressive and another is calm. 
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that changed my life is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book helped me find a wonderful husband and a great job in conservation. I read this book while I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar. I was feeling sad because of many problems, but when I read this book, I felt happy again. It shows animals and people together in a beautiful world. Some people think humans are bad because of what we do to nature. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family. We need to understand this idea.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library when it was first published in 1966. I loved it right away, especially the 48 colorful pictures of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and learned to identify birds during my holidays. But "The Shell Bird Book" had so much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters about bird migration, and even a chapter about birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature more. It showed me that my feelings about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since I was better at art than math, I saw a new path for myself.

DO REVIEWS HELP SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in the newspaper. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or displays in shops. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews. Publishers also feel sad, but they think that any review, good or bad, can help sell books. They like reviews that match their own feelings about a book.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers. Publishers want their books to be reviewed, and they hope for good reviews. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago. However, many paperback books do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find their books. A good review from a trusted person can help sell more books.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Many books are not by famous authors, so publishers need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show the book is good without being paid for. Publishers say they want big reviews, not just good content. Good reviews can help a book sell well, but they need help from other things like word-of-mouth and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the connection between publishing and reviewing is not clear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can make a book popular. In Britain, bookshops may not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews can still sell very well. Non-fiction books let reviewers talk more about the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well. People thought they could learn everything from the reviews and did not need to buy the book. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people listened. Now, sometimes a surprising reviewer can make people want to buy the book.

WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill. It started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes them by hand. 
Graham makes special designs for his customers. He says, "I can make a unique item." Many of his customers are women. They buy gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel, which is a common design. It was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. Graham saw that he could make many different designs. 
He decided to start a weathervane business. Before this, he worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed jobs. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and build his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this is exciting."
Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to detail and asks customers for their approval before cutting the weathervanes. He also keeps traditional designs because people like them too. 
Graham believes people enjoy handmade items. They want something different. He does not want to grow his business too much because he likes it as a small craft. He says, "People love unique items, and I enjoy seeing a simple shape become something special."
For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather. Now, more people are moving to the countryside. They want to add something special to their homes. This helps crafts like Graham's.
Graham is busy and sends weathervanes to customers all over the world. People from America and Denmark are interested in his work. He says, "The price depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**A New Writer's Success**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was a very popular book. It is the first book by Nicholas Evans, a British writer. He earned a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his ideas and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans had a hard time. A film he was working on did not happen. He was sad and worried because he had not made money for two years. He needed money to pay the bank. A smart person would have found a job, but Nicholas did something different. He bought a ticket to America to research his first book for three months.
Nicholas had an idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became very angry. The owners were worried until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and help it. These people are called "horse whisperers." Nicholas liked this idea and wanted to write a story about it.
He drove around the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about his life. He had tried to be a filmmaker for ten years, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.
By the end of August, he had written half of the book. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for it. Nicholas needed this money to pay his debts. He spent seven months writing *The Horse Whisperer* and needed more time to finish it.
In October, he sent the first part of the book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say that they had an offer of $75,000. Nicholas was surprised. After a week of offers, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a lot of money for a first book.
Nicholas could not believe it. He did not send the book to New York, but it got there anyway. Many movie studios wanted to make a film from the book. Nicholas's agent said they could get $3 million for it. Nicholas was shocked.
One night, four famous filmmakers called him to ask for the rights to the book. Nicholas decided not to write the movie script. He thought it was a great story and did not want to spoil it. He wanted to write another book instead.

Bobby Fischer is a famous chess player. He is trying to come back to chess after being away for 20 years. Chess is now a game for younger players. Bobby is 49 years old. He played his old rival, Boris Spassky, and won the first game. But Bobby is not as good as he was in 1972. 
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Now, many players are younger. Most of the top ten players in the world are under 30 years old. Players must prepare a lot before matches. They use computers to study many chess games. 
A chess game can last a long time, sometimes up to eight hours. Players must stay focused. If they make a mistake, they can lose. There is a chess clock that makes the game more exciting. Players have to make their moves quickly. 
Winning a game is very important, but one win is not enough to win a tournament. Tournaments can last 9 to 11 days, and players must play every day. Bobby Fischer wants to show he is still the best player. If he wins, he can earn a lot of money. But if he loses, it could be very sad for him. 
**Questions:**
1. How old is Bobby Fischer?
2. Who did Bobby Fischer play against?
3. How long can a chess game last?
4. What do players use to prepare for matches?
5. What happens if a player makes a mistake during the game?

Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, like poets and pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is a man in his early 30s. He has written three plays. Now, he is making his first play, called Peaches, into a movie. He says, "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented. Before he wrote Peaches, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I did not think it would be shown." The play is set in a car. He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He wanted to write for actors. He liked writing because it has rhythm and rhyme. He says, "I was happy to be with people like me. It was the first time I enjoyed school."
**B** Simon Pegg is 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a TV comedy show and just finished a tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon worked hard from the start. He performed in comedy clubs while at university. He says, "University was very theoretical. I did not want to be a normal actor. I liked comedy more." He thinks comedy is not the hardest job. If you have courage and good ideas, it is great to make people laugh.
**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he danced in the show The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked his performance. He says, "Now I can choose what I want to do." Ciaran acted in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He laughs and says, "I used acting to avoid homework." He decided to take acting seriously because he liked it. Now, he waits for good things to happen. He thinks fame is not what he wants. He says, "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but it is not why you act. You want respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old. He is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They just signed a deal to make three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, hope their single, Chimera, will be a hit. Neil says, "The record company wants big sales, but I just want two people to buy it." He worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for eight years. He was tired and almost gave up when he met Rick Brown. They formed Matrix together. Neil says, "I had some bad times, but I hope it will be worth it."
**E** Stephen Richards is 27 years old. He is a poet and writer. He has won many awards. He is known for his poetry and has been giving readings for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. He says, "It is a story about obsessive love." Stephen liked creative writing in school but did not want to go to university. He got bored working at a theatre and decided to go to university. He published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. He says, "My parents thought I would be a reader, not a writer." He is brave to write novels now. He wants to make sure his writing is good and not just quick.

A. Isabel is 31 years old and studies art. She thinks she looks good in jeans, but she does not wear them often. She wants to find the right man but worries that her knees are not nice. Isabel is hopeful, and this helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way.
B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart boy named Francis works at WLT Radio. The station was started by two men to promote their sandwich shop. Soon, the radio plays many different types of shows with singers and speakers. The author uses humor to show life in a small town and takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s.
C. In this story, a man named Richard talks to his wife’s ex-husband. Richard loves a Russian poetess who writes bad poetry. She wants Richard to help her brother, who is in prison. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way.
D. In London during the 1960s, two sets of best friends meet. One friend, James, is starting a newspaper, and his friend Richard is the editor. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story has love, jealousy, and ambition. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.
E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. He takes care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows the loving relationship Ian has with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book with both sad and funny moments.

Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about volunteer tourism. 
A. Volunteer tourism is when people travel to help others. They can build homes or schools. But, they usually pay a lot of money to do this. If they gave this money to local people, it could help more than their work. Many young people volunteer during their gap years. They often do not have special skills. Some studies ask if these young people want to help others or if they want to help themselves in their careers. However, volunteering can help people learn to care for others in the future.
B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can help solve problems and create connections between people from different countries. This can be good for both the volunteers and the communities they help. But, if only rich people can volunteer, it may not help the communities that need it the most. The volunteers may gain experience, but the local people may not benefit much.
C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves. It can also be a way to help communities with skills and knowledge. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities. It can also make people aware of problems like poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism is popular because it allows people to help others without going through big governments or businesses. This can seem good, but it may not change the real problems in poor communities. Some people think that volunteering is just simple charity. However, when it is called sustainable development, it can be misleading. Volunteer tourism can sometimes ignore the bigger issues of poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?
I tested five clock radios with Tom Granger, an inventor, and Paul Bridges, a broadcaster. One clock radio has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times. One time can be for work days and the other for weekends. But who needs two alarms? 
This clock radio costs about the same as another one we tested. It has a cassette player, so you can listen to your own music when you sleep and wake up to the radio. We all liked the radio quality, but the clock radio is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also likes to book a wake-up call in case the alarm does not work.
This clock radio was voted the best. Paul said he loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it easily. But the buttons felt nice to touch, and I accidentally pressed them too much.
The clock has a backup battery, so you do not have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. However, it was hard to set up. Tom said the clock with a lamp was not good. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The lamp was hard to use, and it only shines on the clock.
Paul thought the lamp idea was funny, but he said the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, and it made me want to throw it away. This model is popular with young people because it is bright and colorful. Tom liked it because it stands out. 
The controls were easy to use, and we could set it up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 20 minutes early or late. Paul laughed at this and said the model was hard to use and not good.
The simplest and cheapest clock radio was liked by Tom because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are not sure if you pressed them right. We thought the tuning was not great, but the radio quality was good. The buzzer worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps! 
**Questions:**
1. What do many people listen to in the morning?
2. What is the purpose of a clock radio?
3. How many clock radios did Stuart test?
4. What feature does the 'dual alarm function' have?
5. What did Paul say he needs space for on his bedside table?
6. What did Tom think about the clock with a lamp?
7. How did the buzzer sound?

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small animal. It has sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many places in the world, but they are not from America or Australia. 
When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a ball. The spines point out to protect it. Some hedgehogs in the desert have fewer spines. They may try to run away instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night. They sleep during the day in bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can sleep for a long time in winter, but not all do. Some stay awake all year.

Great Sportswomen**
It is hard to be good at sports. Women have to work very hard. They train a lot and have little time for normal life. They make sacrifices. But they are winning and breaking records. Here are some British sportswomen who are doing great things.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski. It feels great to jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I feel sick or it is windy, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I don’t see my friends much. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete together."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else! I train for four hours every day. I also swim and run. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because few schools have rowing teams. Most girls start late, so it is hard to be the best. But I love rowing and being fit. It is also fun to be with friends."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very hard. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep. I got a record! Some people think women cannot do this, but I did."
E. **Lisa, 26, Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing is hard. I have to be very competitive. Women have raced cars for a long time, and now more women are joining."
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM to swim three times a week. I also cycle and run. Sometimes I feel tired. I like to keep fit and racing is fun. Men and women race together, but the news talks more about men. We are working to change this."
**Questions:**
1. What sport does Jill do?
2. How long does Caroline train each day?
3. Why is rowing hard for girls, according to Annabel?
4. What did Ffyona want to do when she was 13?
5. What does Lisa think about men drivers?
6. What time does Alison wake up to swim?

One day, Richard Cork, who was 78 years old, met the famous artist Picasso. Richard was a student and was traveling in a van around Europe and Morocco. He ran out of money and found a job painting boats. He liked to draw and had a sketchbook with him.
One day, Richard saw Picasso sitting at a restaurant in Cannes. Picasso was eating lunch with his wife and friends. Richard was surprised to see him there because Picasso usually stayed at home. Richard was nervous, but he went to ask Picasso for his signature. Picasso was nice and signed his name on Richard's paper. Then, he drew some lines on the page too.
Richard wanted to talk to Picasso, but they did not speak the same language well. An American woman at the table helped them talk. She called Picasso "the Maestro." Richard told Picasso that he loved art and admired his work.
After a while, Richard went back to his boat. His friend told him to go back to Picasso and draw his portrait. Richard took his sketchbook and went back to Picasso's table. He did not ask if he could draw him because he was afraid Picasso would say no. Instead, he started to draw.
When Picasso saw Richard drawing, he made funny faces to make it hard for Richard to draw him. Richard wanted to stop, but he kept going because he wanted to do his best. After a few minutes, Picasso stopped making faces and sat still. Richard looked at Picasso carefully. He saw that Picasso looked strong and young for his age.
The American woman told Richard that Picasso wanted to see his drawing. Richard felt shy and said it was not good enough. But Picasso wanted to see it. Richard showed him his drawing, and Picasso smiled at it. Then, Picasso took the crayon and quickly drew a picture of Richard. It was very different from Richard's drawing. Picasso made Richard look funny and happy.
Richard thanked Picasso and asked him to sign the new drawing. The American woman said that Picasso said he already signed Richard's paper. Richard felt lucky to meet Picasso and to have his attention. It was a very special moment for him.

Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you spend more money. 
A. **Fresh Food**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They may also have a bakery that smells like fresh bread. The color green is often used in stores because it makes people think of fresh food.
B. **Product Placement**  
Where products are in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where people look for items. They put popular products at eye level so people can see them easily. Special offers are often in big bins to attract shoppers. Sometimes, they place items that go together near each other, like ice cream and toppings.
C. **Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets may place cheap items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting items. Stores may also put popular products far away, hoping customers will look for them and see other items.
D. **Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show fewer items on the shelves. This makes the clothes look special. Even though they sell many clothes, the store design makes it feel exclusive.
E. **Total Price**  
Shoppers often care more about the total price of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They may sell some items at a loss to attract customers. They also buy in large amounts to get better prices.
F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers notice prices more. For example, a blouse priced at £14.99 seems cheaper than one at £15. This helps reduce theft because workers must ring up sales to give change.
G. **Lighting**  
Stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores use lighting that looks like natural light so shoppers can see colors well. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh food look better.
H. **Store Layout**  
Many stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the way through the store, and another shows sales areas. Some stores use nice carpets to make shoppers want to walk into sales areas.
I. **In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of tasty food. In some places, shopping carts have screens that show ads for products as you shop. This is to catch the attention of shoppers and make them buy more.

Chris Bonnington is a famous mountaineer. He climbed Mount Everest in 1985. He has also climbed in Britain and the Alps and has written many books. Robin Knox-Johnston is a sailor. He was the first person to sail around the world alone in 1968-1969. He sailed in his boat called Sunhaili. He also set a record for sailing from New York to England in 10 days.
Chris and Robin went on a trip to Greenland together. They wrote a book about their trip called Sea, Ice and Rock. Chris called Robin to ask for an interview for his book, Quest for Adventure. Robin invited Chris to sail with him. Chris showed Robin how to climb, and Robin showed Chris how to sail. 
On their trip, they went to a beach. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat. Chris and Robin climbed together. Chris was impressed with how well Robin climbed. Robin asked Chris if he could climb down like he does on his boat. Chris wanted him to use his legs, but Robin used his arms and climbed down safely.
During their trip, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their ideas before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring. He liked being on land more than being on the sea. Robin liked sailing and fixing things on the boat.
When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing. He was worried about Robin's safety. Climbing the highest mountain in Greenland was hard. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours. They were very tired. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. When it was too hard, they turned back. Robin was also worried about their boat.
On the way home, there was a small problem. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his turn to watch the boat, but Robin did not wake him. Chris felt that Robin did not trust him. Robin told Chris that he was wrong to think that. 
After their trip to Greenland, Chris felt they really knew each other. He saw that Robin was a kind and sensitive person. 
**Questions:**
1. Who is Chris Bonnington?
2. What did Chris climb in 1985?
3. What is the name of Robin's boat?
4. What did Chris and Robin write a book about?
5. How did Chris feel about sailing?
6. What did Chris show Robin how to do?
7. What was hard about climbing the mountain in Greenland?
8. How did Chris feel when Robin did not wake him up?

**A Simple History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. 
**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples for thousands of years. In ancient times, they threw away apple seeds. In Switzerland and Italy, people found apple remains near their homes. They even saved apple halves for winter. These apples were small and wild, not like the apples we eat today.
**Learning About Apples (1000 AD)**  
The Romans taught the French how to grow fruit. This knowledge came to Britain. Some apples were brought by the Romans, but many did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to grow new types of apples.
**Popular Apples (1200)**  
In the 1200s, many apples became popular in Britain. One type was called the Old English Pearmain. It was sweet and shaped like a pear. Another type was the Costard, used for cooking. But there were problems like droughts and the Black Death, which made fewer apples grow. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn more about apples. He brought back many new types of apples.
**Apples in New Places (1750)**  
By the 1600s, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in America.
**New Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new type of apple. He named it 'Delicious' because it tasted so good. Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She found a small tree and grew green apples that became very popular.
**Many Apples Today (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from a few types that are easy to transport. Many old apple types are disappearing. People want more kinds of apples. It is important to keep different types of apples for everyone to enjoy.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a travel company that offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We have many unique adventures in over 60 countries around the world. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks and have small groups of about 16 people. This way, you can learn more about the places you visit and meet local people.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport on our trips. You might travel by bus, train, boat, or even on foot! Each trip is special and shows you the local area.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people from places like the UK, Europe, Australia, and Canada. Most are between 25 and 55 years old. Some travel with a partner, and others travel alone. Our trips are for anyone who is healthy and enjoys adventure.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is different. We have 8 categories of adventures, each with special activities. You can see unique places, meet new people, and enjoy different cultures. 
**Cultural Adventures**
Many trips focus on local cultures and history. For example, you can visit Egypt, India, or Greece to see famous sites and learn about different ways of life. Some trips include short walks to explore less-known places.
**Wildlife Safaris**
Our wildlife safaris let you see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can walk in the wild and see amazing animals like gorillas. Most safaris include camping, but some have hotels.
**Meeting Local People**
A special part of our trips is meeting local tribes and ethnic groups. You can learn about their cultures and ways of life. We travel in small groups to help understand and respect different cultures.
**Easy Hiking**
Some trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can stay in hotels or local homes. We have trips in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand.
**Major Treks**
For strong walkers, we offer challenging treks in high mountains. You can stay with local people or camp in the mountains. 
**Wilderness Experiences**
Explore remote areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These trips are for adventurous travelers who want to see beautiful and wild places.
**Sailing and River Journeys**
We also have relaxing boat trips. You can sail in Egypt or travel between islands in Greece. Our river journeys can be short or long, and no experience is needed. You will learn safety skills quickly.
Join us for an adventure of a lifetime!

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners. He visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is in the mountains, ten miles south of the equator. The camp is near Mount Kenya, which is the highest mountain in Kenya. For three years, Richard has trained in this beautiful but quiet place called Nanyuk.
On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard trained with Kenyan runners. He also ran in his first race in Kenya. He was invited to the camp by the Kenyan national team coach after he finished fifth in a big race. This was a great chance for him. Training in the mountains helps runners because it makes their bodies better at using oxygen.
Richard's first race in Africa was special. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa, held in Nairobi. Many Kenyan runners finished ahead of him. Richard felt good about his race, even though he did not win.
Kenyan runners are known for their simple way of training. They run easily and enjoy competing. Richard learned how they train at their camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, high up on Mount Kenya. The athletes live with college students in simple rooms. 
Every day, they have three training sessions: a morning run, interval training, and a steady run in the afternoon. They start their day early, at six in the morning. They run about 40 kilometres each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometres.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, and vegetables. After running, they go to a stream to wash.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just because of their genes or the mountains. It is also about their simple lifestyle, hard work, and love for running.

Advertising is not doing well. This problem started in 1989, before the recession. Advertising is not keeping up with changes in the economy. Advertisers think about big groups of people, but now there are many different groups. Even big brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You may only buy a few advertised brands from many options in the store. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For things like cars, you might only buy one every three years. You do not buy many clothes, and most are not from advertised brands. Overall, you likely do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year.
There are many brands advertised, but most people do not buy them. For example, if you watch TV, you might see many commercials, but you only buy a few of those brands. Most of the commercials are not for brands you buy. Many people think they are not affected by advertising, but that is not true. Most people do not buy most of the brands they see in ads.
Advertising can be wasteful. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. It needs to reach many people to find the few who will buy. Advertisers cannot know who will respond to their ads. Even the best ads do not get a response from everyone.
If an advertiser knows who will buy, they can talk to them directly. This is true for all types of advertising. If an advertiser can get one million new customers, that is very good. For popular products, getting a small percentage of the population to buy is a big success. To do better, advertising needs to focus more on specific groups of people.

Charles Clover visits a special house in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This house is very good for the environment. Near the house is Southwell Minster, a small old cathedral with interesting green figures made by craftsmen long ago.
The house is called the "autonomous house." It was made by Robert and Brenda Vale. They use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle waste into compost for their garden. They also use heat from their appliances and their bodies to warm the house. They live with their three teenage children and two cats named Edison and Faraday.
The house looks traditional with a clay roof. It is quiet inside because it has special windows that keep out noise. When you enter, you must take off your shoes. The house is warm and sunny. The Vales open windows to let fresh air in.
Robert and Brenda teach architecture at a university. They care about the environment and wrote a book about green buildings in the 1970s. They wanted to make a house that does not harm the environment. They do not use city water. They have special toilets and collect rainwater. They do not use dishwashers because they do not want to use strong soaps.
The Vales want to show that it is possible to build a house that is good for the environment. Their house does not have high electricity bills. Last winter, they used very little electricity. Soon, they will add solar panels to make even more electricity. They will use some electricity from the city for cooking, but they will also make extra electricity.
In winter, they have a small wood stove to keep warm, but they do not use it much. One night, Robert said it was too warm to use the stove. The temperature was comfortable because the house keeps the heat inside. 
The house is simple and easy to build. It did not cost much to make because they used local materials and workers. Many big building companies do not like this idea.

The camera never lies
Arthur Conan Doyle wrote the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a smart man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photos of fairies in a garden. He believed these photos showed that fairies were real. He wrote an article and published the photos, saying fairies are wonderful.
In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them in the flowers. The photos are very pretty. But this simple trick shows that the camera can lie. 
Today, we can change photos with computer programs. It is not true that photography was always honest. From the start, when cameras took pictures, they changed what we see.

Blacksmiths**
Blacksmiths are people who work with iron. For a long time, blacksmiths were very important. They made weapons, armor, and tools for farming. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors. They also made beautiful art with iron.
In the 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths in Britain because factories did not need them. But in the last 10 years, more people have become interested in blacksmithing again. They like decorative ironwork and new designs for homes. 
There is an exhibition of blacksmith work at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association, says this could be a new time for blacksmiths. They can now use power tools, which makes their work easier. They can bend and shape iron in new ways.
About 250 pieces of ironwork are in the show. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Some money will help the blacksmiths, and some will help the Association.
Many blacksmiths love working with iron. Susan May, a jeweller, says iron is soft when it is hot but hard when it cools down. Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles. She likes how steel feels cold and hard. 
Iron is a special metal that people enjoy using. It will likely be used for decoration for many years to come.

THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING**
I stopped smoking. I thought my friends would be happy, but one person was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I could not explain how I stopped. It was strange for me too. 
I went to a stop-smoking class two months and three weeks ago. I did not want to stop smoking. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking. I have good health and I do not feel sick. I went to the class to write an article about it. I said, "I will not stop smoking. I am here to write, not to stop." I liked smoking. It made me happy.
In the class, we could smoke as much as we wanted. The room was full of smoke. But when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. I think the messages about stopping smoking made sense. I started to think that stopping smoking was a good idea. I felt strong. 
It was not hard to stop. The desire for cigarettes went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was easy. The hardest part was being at home on weekends. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. 
I miss smoking a little, but not too much. Now, I have to think about new things as a non-smoker. Eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, and waiting at the theater are all moments when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is a British woman scientist. She won the Nobel Prize, but many people do not know her name. For four years, I have asked my friends about her. When I tell them I am writing a book about Dorothy Hodgkin, some say, "Isn't there already a book about her?" If they know her, they pass my test.
Dorothy Hodgkin is important because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. If someone in literature won a Nobel Prize, everyone would know their name. Dorothy died in 1994. She was a special person and studied crystals. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like better education for women and the growth of science around the world.
When I started my research, I wanted to read about other scientists. A friend told me to read about Linus Pauling. He was a friend of Dorothy and worked in the same field. I went to a bookstore, but I could not find a book about him. I was surprised because he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes for chemistry and peace.
Some scientists think that biographies are not interesting. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often boring. If scientists think this, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores think the same way. Many famous scientists do not have biographies in bookstores.
It is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists or writers. Some scientists do not want to be in the media because they do not want to seem like they are showing off. This makes people think science is not interesting, which can stop young people from wanting to be scientists.
Today, more scientists are seen in public. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people.
The world of books is changing too. Scientific biographies used to be boring and only about work. They did not talk much about the scientist's life outside of work, like family and personal life. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show scientists as real people with feelings and problems.
Dorothy Hodgkin loved her work. She solved the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in 1964. She also worked on insulin in 1969. She had three children and a husband who was often away for work. Her personal life is important, and we can learn from how she balanced her work and family.
Dorothy Hodgkin's life is interesting to everyone, not just scientists. She was very passionate about science, which is important for any successful scientist. It is hard for writers to show this passion because many readers do not know enough science. But understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just takes practice.
It is sad that many educated people do not know about important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, but they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

Margaret and Her Water Finding**
Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers need her help because their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines, but Margaret uses the hazel stick to find water.
Margaret is very good at her job. She finds water more than 90 out of 100 times. This skill is called dowsing. Some people think it is magic, while others think it is about how things vibrate. Water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water.
In recent years, many farmers have come to Margaret for help. She usually sees each customer only once because wells last a long time. Some customers have holiday homes and need water. Others are building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to find clean water. She needs electricity to pump the water, so the well should be close to power sources.
To start, Margaret looks at a map and uses a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map. If it swings, there may be water there. Then, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels something special. She uses the stick to find the best place to drill.
Margaret holds the stick with both hands. If the stick rises, it means water is below. It is important to drill in the right spot. If she and her husband do not agree on where to drill, they keep looking until they do.
Margaret's skill is interesting to many people. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding where water is. Because of this skill, she and her family can keep their well-drilling business going year after year.

**We changed lives for a day!** 
Have you ever wanted to live like someone else for a day? We helped four people do this. 
**Amanda's story**  
Amanda is 23 years old. She is a mother with two daughters. She changed lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 years old and works in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda went to the restaurant. It was dark and loud. There were many people. It was very different from her home. She had to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. It was hard! The drinks fell and made a mess. Amanda felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. They said everyone makes mistakes at first. 
At 11:30 am, many customers came. Amanda felt nervous. She was worried about remembering the orders, but it was easy because there was a computer system. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. 
At 5 pm, Amanda was very tired. She was happy to go home to her children. She thought being a waitress was hard work!
**Cindy's story**  
Cindy is 30 years old. She was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. Amanda's daughters were cheeky, and Cindy thought she could handle it. 
Cindy had to dress and feed the girls. After taking Sophie to school and Katie to nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she had to clean the house and do laundry. 
At 1 pm, Cindy took Katie home for lunch. When Sophie came home, they started playing and making noise. Cindy tried to relax, but the girls had a lot of energy! 
At 8 pm, Cindy finally got the girls to bed. But then they wanted more water and to watch TV. Cindy realized that taking care of children is very tiring. She enjoyed the day, but it was hard work!
**Rosemary's story**  
Rosemary is 42 years old. She runs a farm. She got to sleep in until 7 am, which was nice! At school, she felt nervous in front of many students. 
In class, the children worked in groups. They did a nature project with snails. At lunchtime, teachers only have five minutes to eat. Rosemary helped with a meeting and then with sports. 
She was tired, but the children had a lot of energy. Speaking in front of the class was hard for her. She liked farming more than teaching.
**Hilary's story**  
Hilary is 30 years old. She went to Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am. Rosemary had been working for three hours already! 
On the farm, there are many animals. Hilary worked in the ice-cream shop, filling bottles and making ice-cream. She wanted to eat some! 
At lunchtime, she checked the sheep. If a sheep falls, it needs help quickly. Hilary milked the cows, which took a long time. 
Hilary felt lonely without children. Farming is hard work, and there is not much time off. Rosemary only gets a few days of holiday each year. Farming is not as easy as it seems. 
---
**Questions:**
1. How old is Amanda?
2. What job does Cindy have?
3. What did Amanda feel when the drinks fell?
4. How did Cindy feel about taking care of the girls?
5. What did Hilary do at the farm?
6. How many days of holiday does Rosemary get?

Hakan Hardenberger is a famous trumpet player from Sweden. He was born in a small town and his parents did not play music. When he was eight years old, his father gave him a real trumpet for Christmas. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a good trumpet player. Bo saw that Hakan had a special talent.
Hakan liked to play alone and wanted to be a solo artist. He admired a French trumpet player named Maurice Andre. Hakan's parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player. When he was 16, he went to Paris to study with another teacher, Pierre Thibaud. 
Hakan entered a music competition when he was 17. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and learned that people liked to listen to him. Hakan believes that music can touch people's hearts. He thinks it is important to play from the heart and not just to win prizes.

A. The story is about a man named Tristan Smith who lives in a made-up country called Efica. The book talks about power, history, and funny moments. The writer has made a special world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and interesting, but it can be hard to read.
B. Harriet is a woman with a good job and a husband who is an architect. She meets Sheila, a woman who takes care of her old father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo hurts Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about what happened. Leo was a good student and never fought before, but he does not explain why he did it. Joe gets better but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son and takes care of him all the time. Sheila feels very guilty and wants to meet Harriet. This meeting helps them become friends. The writer shows how people feel when bad things happen in their lives.
C. This book is about a small island in Scotland and the people who live there. It tells the story of a boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears for a while and comes back after the Second World War. He learns to appreciate the simple life of his ancestors.
D. The author has written a new book after a big success. It is about a woman named Aurora Greenway, who is now in her seventies. She has a friend named Rosie. Aurora is still charming and kind, and Rosie helps her with her life. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and new people are coming into her life. The writer shows the sadness that can be under normal life.
E. Six different people come together to sail in the South Pacific on a yacht called the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to tell their stories of self-discovery. Each person learns something new about themselves while sailing on the ocean. The writer uses strong images to show ideas about memory and awareness.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share what they like, what is hard, and what they do every day.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am. I go to the gym at 7:00 am. I get to work by 8:00 am and start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes I work for ten hours without a break. It can be stressful to decide what to do. I feel okay when I am in surgery, but I worry about the next day. Surgery is very important for patients. I have an out-patients' clinic from 10:00 am to 1:00 pm. I talk to patients about their surgery. I like this part of my job. I leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. Sometimes I work at night or on weekends. I think about my patients even when I am on holiday."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am and leave home by 8:20 am. I take the train to work and arrive at 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to talk about our work. I work with a team of four people. I spend three or four weeks designing projects. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like my ideas, we make plans and budgets. I work with printers and make sure everything is on time. I have lunch at 1:00 pm for one hour. I like it when clients like my designs, but it is sad when they do not. I go home at 7:30 pm or later."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:00 am most days. Some days, I wake up very early to meet flights. I might go for a bike ride or swim at 10:30 or 11:00 am. I have to eat healthy food because I sit a lot in my job. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. I need to know good restaurants and shops for my passengers. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:00 am and leave home at 7:30 am. I work in gardens that I designed. I spend about one and a half hours at each garden. At 11:00 am, I go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I work until 10:00 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I work from home in the office too. I talk to clients in the evening about their gardens. I like to use old materials to make gardens look nice. It is hard to relax at night because I hear the phone ring. I sleep well because my job is very physical."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at work by 8:30 am. I help build bridges and walls. I check that the workers are doing their jobs safely. I talk to the workers and solve problems. The workers start at 6:00 am, so I ask what happened before I arrived. I usually have lunch for half an hour at 2:00 pm. I eat while I work. I leave work at about 6:00 pm and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**
A. **Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and go to work by 7:30 am. I help customers who use our credit cards. I talk to card users and try to get new customers. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then I check my emails. I have many meetings during the day. I also travel to different places in Europe to meet with customers. I finish work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
B. **Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail and listen to music tapes from new artists. I have meetings to talk about music projects. I help choose songs and work with the artists. I leave work at 7:00 pm. Sometimes I go to concerts and get home around 1:00 am.
C. **Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and arrive at work by 9:30 am. I check the mail and see if we have clients to meet. I enjoy selling furniture. I read about antiques while I drink coffee. I do the accounts once a month. I go home at 5:30 pm.
D. **Air Traffic Controller**  
I leave home at 6:00 am for my early shift. I start work at 7:00 am. I help control the planes in the sky. I work with a team and we talk to each other. I find this job stressful, and I want to be a manager one day.
E. **Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home at 8:00 am. I start the cash register and help customers find books. I talk to book representatives about new books. I finish work at 5:45 pm. Sometimes I work late and close the shop.
F. **Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am and take a taxi to work by 8:45 am. I talk to reporters about news in my area. I help companies understand financial risks. I write reports and send them to my editor. I travel to Africa a few times a year. I leave work around 6:00 pm. I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Be a Good Leader at Work**
A. **What is a good leader?**  
A good leader is someone who inspires others. They help people and show them the way. Being a leader is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about work, says that a leader makes things happen with the help of enthusiastic people. A good leader should speak clearly and confidently. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. **Everyone can be a leader.**  
John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says that many people can be better leaders than they think. To be a leader, you need to find your talents and use them. We all have the ability to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow.
C. **Think about your best and worst boss.**  
Your best boss helped you and motivated you. Your worst boss made you feel small and did not share information. The best boss led well, while the worst boss just managed badly.
D. **Leaders and managers are different.**  
Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. A good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad company into a happy one.
E. **Improve your leadership skills.**  
1. Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you love and use that energy to lead.  
2. Think of yourself as a leader. You have the power to lead.  
3. Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different ways of leading. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try to take charge instead.  
4. Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where you can be a better leader.
F. **Leadership takes practice.**  
1. You become a leader by taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to share tasks and motivate others.  
2. Your way of leading may not always please everyone. Keep working on how you communicate.  
3. Be present and available for important people.  
4. You don’t have to lead all the time. Know when you are needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

Films on Video**
**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**
**A. Abyss**  
This movie is about a group of oil workers and navy experts. They try to save a nuclear submarine that is very deep in the ocean. The main character, Bud, and his team are brave and funny. The special effects in the movie are very good, but the story is not very strong.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about a battle in Guadalcanal. It is directed by Andrew Marton. This version is more traditional than another version by Terrence Malick. Marton focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is more artistic, but Marton's film has some good moments.
**C. On Guard**  
This movie is based on a book from 1875. It is a fun adventure with swords. The villain is a bad politician, and the hero is a brave man. The film has many funny and exciting moments, even if it uses some old ideas.
**D. Character**  
This movie is set in Rotterdam a long time ago. The costumes and sets look very real, like a museum. The main character, Dreverhaven, is a cruel man who treats his son badly. The story is dark, but the film focuses too much on the details.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This movie is about three men: a good man, a bad man, and an ugly man. They all do bad things in the West after the Civil War. The music is very exciting, and the sound is very clear. 
**F. The Longest Day**  
This is a long war movie with many famous actors. It shows the story of soldiers waiting for an invasion. The beginning is slow, and the movie is better on a big screen. Watching it on video is not as good.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is a good book. The main character is a lawyer. He is trying to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife because she is accused of killing her husband. The trial is exciting, and the end is surprising. This is a great first book.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. The main character, Sigismondo, helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He gets into trouble with politics and murder, but we know he will find the bad people. The story is complicated and a bit long, but it is still very good.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She sees a strange man fall down and die. Leah is brave and smart, and she solves the mystery even when people do not believe in her.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker is about a private investigator named Spenser. He helps his friend Hawk to get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The story has fast dialogue and some deep thoughts. It is always good entertainment from Parker.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has two detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a robbery at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The writing is easy to read and funny, making it an enjoyable mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife, Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It is about a lawyer and his female client. The story happens outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a thrilling story.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher. He is supposed to be the victim in a movie about Robin Hood. The story has funny characters, but Philip does not like how his career is going. Simon Shaw usually writes well, but this time it is not his best work.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is a good book by Lawrence Gough. It is about Canadian police who are looking for a bank robber. The robber targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the clever robber, making it better than most detective novels.
---
**Questions:**
1. What is the main character's job in *Compelling Evidence*?
2. Who helps rich people in *Curtains for the Cardinal*?
3. What does Leah Hunter see in *File Under: Deceased*?
4. What does Spenser help his friend with in *Double Deuce*?
5. Who are the detectives in *False Prophet*?
6. What happens to the lawyer in *Blood Red, Snow White*?
7. What movie is Philip Fletcher working on in *Dead for a Ducat*?
8. Who do the police look for in *Fall Down Easy*?

Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for one year. Tim feels nervous about this. He has traveled before. After university, he traveled in North and South America for two years. When he came back, he got a job, bought a flat, and started earning money. But he felt he was not happy with just working for money. 
When he quit his job, he felt good. He has no big responsibilities now. Many of his friends are married and have children. They are happy for him because he can travel. Tim is nervous because he has to make plans. He worries about renting his flat and where to go. He is also behind on his plans. 
Tim knows many people in their thirties want to travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people want adventures. They realize they can travel if they are brave and organized. 
Danny is 30 years old. He is an accountant. He and his girlfriend Tammy, who is 28 and a teacher, bought tickets to travel around the world for a year. Danny says he is ready to give up job security for this trip. 
Matt just left the Army. He traveled for a year to change his life. He wanted to live differently. Angela Baron says many people work on short contracts now. If a contract ends, they can travel. 
Dan Hiscocks says many people in their thirties think about their lives. If they are not happy, they want to change. Travel helps them think about what they want. 
Jennifer Cox believes this is a good thing. People want to live balanced lives. Ben is 32 years old and going to Central America for a year. He is not running away; he wants to find new things for himself. 
Ben feels nervous about leaving his routine. Tim also feels unsure about leaving his comfortable life. Sometimes, a big change, like losing a job or a relationship, makes people want to travel. 
Tim is excited about the next year. He wants to enjoy life and travel. He believes many people like him feel the same way. 
---
**Questions:**

2. Where does Tim want to travel?
3. What did Tim do after university?
4. Why did Tim feel good when he quit his job?
5. What do Danny and Tammy plan to do?
6. What did Matt want to change in his life?
7. Why do many people in their thirties want to travel?
8. How does Ben feel about leaving his routine?

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt she did not know much about new technology. In this story, she talks about how she changed her home to work better.
Last Christmas, I turned 37 years old. I wanted to go back to my job in journalism, but I felt lost. My resume showed that I was stuck in the past, like in the 1980s. Back then, I used a typewriter, and now everyone uses computers. I thought it would be hard to find a job because I did not know how to use a computer.
I thought it would be difficult to leave home before my children went to school. But then, I entered a contest in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for everyone. We started to learn about the Internet and how to chat with people from around the world. My children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was scared to use the computer because I thought I would lose my work. But I learned how to use it, and it was easier than I thought.
Now, I write articles for a magazine. I can work from home and still take my children to school. The computer helps me stay organized. I can keep track of money and write letters quickly. I can also find information online for my stories and talk to other writers.
But working from home has some problems. Sometimes, I feel lonely because I do not see many people. There are also distractions at home, like chores and my children wanting to use the computer. Many people in my neighborhood are also using computers for work and fun.
A report says that many people who work from home are educated and own computers. I feel good because I am learning and using technology. One day, I hope to send my articles to a newspaper in Australia or even start my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless! 
**Questions:**
1. What job did Georgina McGuiness have before her break?
2. How old did Georgina turn last Christmas?
3. What did Georgina win in the contest?
4. What do Georgina's children know how to use well?
5. What does Georgina use the computer for?

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has a modern building that looks like a cheese wedge. The outside is very big and bright. People have different opinions about the building. Some think it is beautiful, while others do not like it.
Inside the museum, there are many interesting things to see. The museum tells stories about Scotland's history. There are important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show the truth about the past.
Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants everyone to enjoy their visit. The museum is for all people, even those who do not know much about history. There are no fake scenes; everything shown is real.
The museum has many spaces to explore. There are different rooms with light coming in from the windows. You can take your time to look at everything. There is also a special area for children to learn and play.
On the top floor, there is a gallery that changes every three years. People from Scotland choose objects that are important to them, like toys and guitars. This is a fun idea, but some think it is not serious enough.
Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum is beautiful inside, but some wonder if it is in the right place.

The end of print newspapers may take some time. "Transition" is a nice word. It means moving from one place to another. Some people may be scared of change, but it can also be good. 
Now, newspapers are moving to the internet. This is not easy. Many people do not buy print newspapers anymore, but more people visit their websites. For example, sales of newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian are down by 8% to 10% each year. But their websites are getting more visitors.
However, not everything is bad. A survey showed that the number of newspapers sold around the world went up by 1.1% last year. In Asia, more people are buying newspapers. Some magazines also saw an increase in sales.
E-books are very popular now, and many people are buying them. But when stores looked at the sales of real books, they found that sales were only down by 0.4%. This means people still like both e-books and real books.
Many young people still read newspapers. In fact, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main newspapers in the UK. Different countries have different stories. In Britain, newspaper sales are down by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%. In France, it is just 3.1%.
Some people thought that online ads would help newspapers make money. But now, online ads are going down. Many US newspapers have started to charge for their online content. The best way to get readers is to offer both a print copy and online access together. 
Print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. They make much more money from print ads than from online ads. However, it is hard for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. But print newspapers still have a strong presence, and it is harder to be noticed online. 
**Questions:**
1. What does "transition" mean?
2. Are more people visiting newspaper websites or buying print newspapers?
3. How much did the number of newspapers sold go up last year?
