**Photographing People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually better than a photo without a person. But taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must pay attention to how people move and what they do. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking a photo of a group, do not make them stand in a straight line. Ask them to stand at different angles and distances. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all their faces.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting they put their hands in their pockets or fold them.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when you are. Most people will agree to have their picture taken. They may feel shy, so you might need to help them feel comfortable.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They may not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real smile.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural. Candid shots can show real feelings.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
The way a person looks and moves tells us a lot about them. A happy child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for different expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up.
**G. Situation Interest**  
The background of a photo can add more meaning. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger compared to the background.
**H. Interaction**  
Photos of people talking, laughing, or working together can be very good. Look for moments when people connect, like a handshake or a smile.
**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken on trips. To show both the person and the place, step back to get everything in the picture. Make sure the people are close to the camera but do not block the background.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Think about why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose nicely. But for family photos, candid shots of real moments can be more fun and memorable.

Sarah Janson, the Artist**
Sarah Janson is an artist. She paints in a special way called trompe-l'oeil. This means her paintings look real, like they are not just pictures. Joanna Watt is talking to her in an interview.
Sarah does not like to sign her paintings. She thinks the painting is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not about me, it's about the work." At first, she feels shy about talking about herself. When Joanna asks to take her picture, Sarah covers her face because she feels embarrassed.
After a little time, Sarah feels better. The interview becomes fun and interesting. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she studied art for two years and worked in a publishing house. She did not like illustration, so she started working with a special decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to do one trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it.
Sarah says that you cannot learn trompe-l'oeil from a school. You learn by looking at things. She is always learning new things. She is honest about what she cannot do well. For example, she says, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." 
Once, she had to paint a big ceiling at Lulworth Castle. She got confused with the measurements and thought, "Who do you think you are?" She often talks about herself in a funny way, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"
Sarah's paintings are very special. Many people want her to paint for them. She gets ideas from buildings. For example, she painted a dining room that looks like a beautiful building in Venice. She also painted a hallway that looks like it has two more rooms.
Sarah knows that trompe-l'oeil must be clever and interesting. It should make people think and feel. She loves to work with her clients. Some clients know what they want, and some do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their ideas. Many of her clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them.
Sarah is thankful for her clients. She says, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, and that is why she is always busy. At the end of the interview, she says again, "I really don't like to shout about myself." She wants her work to be quiet and not loud. But her work is very special, and many people should know about it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman talks about important skills for success at work.
A. The rules for work are changing. We are not just judged by how smart we are or by our training. We are also judged by how we manage ourselves and how we work with others. This is important when companies choose who to hire. It helps to show who will do well at work and who may not. These new rules are different from what we learned in school. Doing well in tests is not as important anymore. Now, it is more about social skills and personal qualities, like being friendly, understanding others, and being flexible. These skills are called emotional intelligence.
B. Today, many jobs do not have security. People need to have skills that they can use in different jobs. Personal qualities are very important at work. Emotional intelligence means understanding and managing our own feelings and the feelings of others. It helps us think and act better. In our work, it includes being aware of ourselves, controlling our feelings, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means being nice. But sometimes, it means being honest, even if it is uncomfortable. It is not about showing all our feelings. It is about managing our feelings so we can work well with others.
C. More companies are seeing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. In jobs that are not simple, emotional intelligence is even more important. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard to use their knowledge. Many people have succeeded without strong emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for doing well in any job.
D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their feelings and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our jobs. This is important now, as jobs are not always stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore it, other things may not work as well.

**Acupuncture and Traditional Chinese Medicine**
Acupuncture is a type of medicine from China. It is over 2,000 years old. Acupuncture is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Many doctors in the West use acupuncture to help with pain.
**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**
In traditional Chinese medicine, health means that the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. There is a special energy called Qi (pronounced "chee") that flows in the body. This energy moves along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to organs in the body. If the flow of Qi is blocked, a person can feel weak or sick.
When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health and habits. They use very thin needles to help the flow of Qi. Sometimes, they use heat from herbs or apply pressure to certain points.
**Acupuncture Points**
There are over 300 points on the meridians where acupuncturists can place needles. These points may not be near the area that hurts. People often feel a gentle ache or tingling when the needle is used. This means the needle is working with the Qi.
**How Does Acupuncture Work?**
Doctors in the West believe acupuncture can help with pain. They think it may block pain signals or release natural pain-relieving substances in the body.
**What Pain Can Acupuncture Help?**
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture. It can help with back pain, headaches, arthritis, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain from serious illnesses.
**Using Acupuncture in Surgery**
Acupuncture has been used in China for a long time, but using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. In China, acupuncture is used in many surgeries. Some people say it helps reduce pain without side effects.
**Is Acupuncture Always Effective?**
Studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find acupuncture helps with chronic pain. It may take six to seven visits to feel better, but some people feel improvement after two or three visits.
**A Different Way to Treat Pain**
Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They ask many questions to understand the pain better. They want to know if the pain feels sharp or dull and if it gets worse in different weather. This is different from how many doctors treat pain.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. They should refer you to a doctor if you need more help.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems calm and strong, but she is shy. P.D. James created a detective named Adam Dalgliesh. She says he is like her, but if she were a man. Adam likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James likes to write alone. She needs quiet time to write.
Many people read her books. She has written 12 detective novels. P.D. James likes the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, who writes under the name Barbara Vine. She also enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she likes some men writers too, like Graham Greene.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there. Life was hard for her at times. Her husband was sick after the war, and she had to work a lot to take care of him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband’s parents helped take care of the girls.
P.D. James worked for the National Health Service and then for the Home Office. She worked with police and learned about crime. She saw dead bodies but did not like death. She loved writing detective stories because they are interesting. She wanted to be a serious writer. She thought writing detective stories was a good way to learn about writing. She believes that solving a crime in a story brings order to chaos and shows that life is important, even if it is hard.

The pen is stronger than the doctor. People are studying handwriting to learn about a person's character. In some countries, if you want a job, you may need to show your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Some researchers say it can help show certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer, and can show feelings and mental states.
Many big companies now use graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. But many doctors do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne is a graphologist with over 20 years of experience. She thinks doctors should pay more attention to handwriting. She believes handwriting can show mental traits and some health issues. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if a person should study arts or sciences."
According to Ms. Marne, handwriting can help find out if someone might be a criminal. She says, "Criminals often have bad handwriting. They may have had a hard life and may not have grown emotionally. This can show in childish handwriting." She can tell if people are honest or not. 
Ms. Marne says that handwriting can show if someone is under stress or has mental problems. It can also show health issues with the heart and lungs. She says, "You cannot make a diagnosis from one sample. But if handwriting changes over time, it could mean something serious is happening." 
Ms. Marne explains that handwriting can show other traits. For example, if letters are connected like threads, the person may be clever but not honest. If someone writes mostly in capital letters, they may be hiding their true self. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity. If handwriting is very small, it may mean the person feels shy. 
Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to analyze handwriting well. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She thinks it is better than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history without asking questions. 
However, many doctors do not agree. They say handwriting is just a result of education and has no special meaning. 
**Questions:**
1. What is graphology?
2. Why do some companies use graphologists?
3. What can handwriting show about a person?
4. How long does it take to learn to analyze handwriting?
5. What do some doctors think about graphology?

Is your office good to work in? Fresh air and good chairs are important for happy and healthy workers, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies work conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**  
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no air conditioning. The windows open to the street. The workers are happy and work well together. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, like at home.  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture does not match. Some chairs are old and broken. This is not good for health. But the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This helps them not feel tired or bored.  
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The workers like the variety of tasks. They say the office is "just the right size" – small enough to know each other, but big enough to work alone. The office is fun and creative.
**Office B: News Service**  
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air is good, and there is a No Smoking policy.  
- **Ergonomist:** The chairs are very good, and the lighting is nice. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The walls are plain and boring.  
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls have some planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most workers have been there for five years and get along well. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information easily.
**Office C: Bank**  
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has mixed feelings from workers. It feels like being in a glass box. The air is not stale, even with smokers nearby.  
- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and not inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for working on computers.  
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The workers help each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the colors are dark.
**Office D: Newspaper**  
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not good. The air conditioning does not work well, and the temperature changes a lot. The space is messy, and there is too much dust.  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is not good for working. Many chairs are old and do not help workers.  
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is dirty, with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. Workers seem stressed and do not talk much. The company should encourage teamwork.
---
**Questions:**
1. What is important for happy and healthy workers?
2. How do workers in Office A change the temperature?
3. What is one problem with the furniture in Office B?
4. How do workers feel in Office C?
5. What needs to be improved in Office D?

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular in America. People chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. It is a type of food and must follow rules from the American Food and Drug Administration.
Today, most gum is made with chemicals. It has added ingredients to keep the flavor and make it soft. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a natural gum from a tree called the mastic tree. Women in Greece used it to clean their teeth and make their breath fresh.
In America, colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans. They chewed a resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people sold spruce gum in the eastern United States. This was the first commercial chewing gum in America.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with a substance called chicle. Chicle comes from the sapodilla tree in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew. However, it is hard to find chicle now. 
Today, many gum makers use synthetic materials instead of chicle. The few people who still gather chicle, called chicleros, have a tough life. They walk for miles in hot and humid conditions to collect the sap from the trees. They face dangers like snakes and insects. 
Chicleros take the sap to a camp, where they boil it to make it sticky. Their food is often just maize and a local drink made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. 
In the past, the United States imported a lot of chicle from Central America. But now, much less chicle is collected. As gum sales have increased, companies use more synthetic materials to save money.
Chewing gum is said to help with relaxation and reduce tooth decay. When we eat, acid forms in our mouths. Chewing gum can help our saliva fight this acid. Gum makers say that chewing for 20 minutes can help our saliva flow more.
There are many new flavors and types of gum. Some flavors are natural, but many are made with chemicals. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the most popular chewing gums.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. At the Globe Hotel, things are not going well. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not see Sue and Christopher. Sue thinks this is very bad. 
The Globe Hotel has three red stars. This means it is one of the best hotels. But when Sue arrives, she does not feel welcome. The door to the hotel is not nice, and the hallway is long and empty.

Doug Scott is a mountaineer. He climbed the highest mountains on each continent. This is called the Seven Summits. He climbed these mountains later in his life. 
A. **Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his friend Dougal were in a snow cave. They were 91 meters below the top. Dougal talked about sleeping bags, which was strange because only they were there. Doug felt cold in his feet and remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes. He thought about how to climb better to reach the top.
B. **Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal went to the Kahiltna Glacier. They carried equipment and food for four days. They climbed a new route to the top. They were very tired but finally reached the summit and felt happy.
C. **Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. They got lost in the jungle but found a rock pool with water. They decided to take a different route to the top of Kilimanjaro.
D. **Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. They walked with many other people to the top. They camped outside before going back down.
E. **Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif needed money to get there. In November 1992, his team went to the South Pole. The sun was always shining. On December 7, they climbed to the top in a storm. They were happy but could not see much.
F. **Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In summer 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They took a cable car to 3,900m. They walked to a refuge. After two days, they thought they reached the top, but there was more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then went down.
G. **Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
Doug wanted to climb Carstensz and meet the local Dani people. They were warned about dangers but still went. On May 12, they climbed and reached the top by 11 am. Doug felt proud to finish climbing all seven summits.
---
**Questions:**

8. What did Doug's team do at Vinson Massif?

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today. It is in our clothes, homes, and accessories. Jo Foley talks about the fashion trends this year.

Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says, "People should choose simple styles, not stiff or frilly dresses." He has been drawing and designing dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You do not have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress. He also makes long evening dresses in new colors and fabrics. Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewellery. She started designing rings when she could not find one she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. She has a big garden around her house. This garden has many flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. There are two long flower beds along a path in the garden. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The people who lived there before Susan were good gardeners. They left many plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. 
Susan says, "It was really his garden." She and Danny worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of the flowers Susan wanted to paint. But when she told him she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. Sometimes she picks a flower and takes it to her studio. She does not paint everything at once. She paints one flower, which can take a few days. Then she brings in another flower. Sometimes it takes a long time to finish a painting.
Spring and early summer are busy times for Susan. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. She loves to see how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they may seem boring, but they become interesting.
Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers that grew in tough places, like rocks or cliffs.
Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they are careful. 
Susan is busy preparing for two art shows. She has a lot of flowers to paint, but she finds it hard to work in the garden. She now has another gardener to help her. Even though she is busy, she knows that to paint flowers well, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Many trees in Brackham fell down in a big storm in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the market square. This made the town look very different, and some people were not happy about it.
Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham was the head of the local police. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and a tight chest. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he did not want to go. He thought the police needed him. He tried to keep working, but he felt worse.
Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too tired to argue. Soon, he got medicine and went home. Molly sent him to bed. 
On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen down. Pelham was too sick to understand. On Thursday evening, he asked if the house was okay. When he heard it was fine, he felt relieved and went back to bed.
On Saturday, Pelham felt better. He got up and saw that the living room looked different without the walnut tree. Their house had a big garden, and Pelham liked it. The garden made them feel private. 
Before, the walnut tree made the living room look nice. Now, without the tree, the room was too bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to Molly. But Molly seemed happy. “I told you we need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

Living in the Valley**
We lived in our valley for sixteen months. One day, we saw that the hills around us could be dangerous. It was a year when storms came early, before winter. Until then, we felt safe in our valley. 
Then, snow began to fall. In one day, there was 15 centimeters of snow. The snow blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery. In the hills, the snow was deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some wind. The trees moved, but they did not break. 
We were worried about the river, the Ryburn. It usually flowed gently, but now it was dangerous. Many years ago, people built dams to control the water from the hills. 
Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills. The clouds looked scary. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted, and rain came from the clouds. The reservoir in the hills was filling up quickly. 
Then, the reservoir overflowed for the first time in years. Water poured over the dam like a waterfall. The river became wild and deep near our cottage. For three days, we hoped the river would not flood. Luckily, the dam held, and the water went down. 
Before the dam was built, the river flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam keeps the river safe. We can enjoy the clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He has worked for a newspaper called The Front Page for ten years. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before this, he wrote reviews for books and films for other newspapers and magazines. He also worked for the radio. 
He met Tom Seaton, who was the first arts editor of The Front Page. Tom hired Mark. Tom was not a journalist, so he did not choose his staff carefully. He wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have lunch together every week to talk about what to write. Mark felt happy to be part of a new newspaper. 
At first, Mark was surprised when he saw someone reading The Front Page on the London Underground. They were reading a page with his review. Mark did not feel confident. 
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, so they talked by phone. People liked to read reviews from critics who focused on one subject. Mark chose to write about films. 
Now, Mark writes a long article every week about one film. He likes this way of working. He does not want to be a standard film critic who watches every new film. He thinks that would make him tired of his job. 
Mark believes people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. He thinks a film review is not just a guide for buying tickets. He does not feel he must always be right about a film. He just wants to share his opinion. He does not want to be a judge of films. 
**Questions:**
1. What is Mark Adams' job?
2. What newspaper does he work for?
3. Who hired Mark?
4. What did Mark write about before working for The Front Page?
5. How does Mark feel about writing one long article about a film each week?

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 
Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves sports. She is looking for a training partner who also likes to swim, cycle, and run. It is important to be very interested in running long distances, swimming in cold water, and cycling long distances. You need to do all three sports without taking a break.
The triathlon is a popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. It looks hard, but Melanie thinks it is fun. 
Melanie started doing triathlons when she was 14 years old. She won her first race, but she was the only junior in it. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. She swam fast and ran fast, but she got lost and cycled too far. She cried while running, but she did not give up. 
Melanie works very hard. She is the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships. She finished 13th. She wants to get better at cycling. She is asking her parents to buy her a new bike for the World Championships in New Zealand. 
Melanie trains a lot, so she does not go out with friends. She says, "I don't have a social life." After swimming for two hours, she just wants to sleep. But she still talks to her teammates about their times in races. 
Melanie has tried shorter races, but she wants to do even harder events. She says, "The big trouble is, I have no one my age to train with."

The Collectors**
Amanda Roy writes about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. Many adults enjoy collecting. It is a fun and exciting world. But if you want to collect something, remember: you should love the object. 
People have collected things for a long time. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.
I have collected things all my life. I started with stones from my parents' garden when I was six years old. I went to a school in a cold place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people. I loved looking at them.
Many adults also like to collect. Some people collect because it makes them feel in control. For me, I just enjoy it. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful things. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had more than 4,000 paintings.
You do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I got a special tulip from another collector. I planted it, but one year it disappeared. Someone took it!
I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I looked all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost in a fire. The next day, I saw the burned remains of my dolls and furniture. I was very sad.
I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king is very valuable. When small objects become popular, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you keep the original boxes. I wish I had kept mine!

**My Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Organiser at the Science Museum**  
I help create exhibitions. I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the topic and talk to important people to find out what to show. I make sure visitors can understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities and make sure everything is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help make brochures and leaflets to tell people about it.
**Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers**  
I start work at 7:30 a.m. I check the accounts. I make new maps and documents for taxi drivers. By midday, about 50 students are in school. They learn the best routes to take. If they disagree, I help them find the right way. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route. I help them think about different ways to go.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but I mostly work by the coast. I work with schools and teach people about the sea. I take them out on a boat to show them the life under the water. I love my job because I care about conservation. But I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money to do my work.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is different every day. I make sure we have the right books and keep enough in stock. We have high standards for our information. We get many letters from readers about maps, and I answer them carefully. I talk about future projects with my team. I enjoy working with my team, but I have a lot of paperwork, which takes time away from more fun tasks like creating new products.

We always went to Ireland in June. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me, Milly, spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, Mr. and Mrs. Malseed, own the house. They made it bigger, but it looks nice. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement a long time ago.
Last summer, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was bad. We have played cards together for a long time. My real name is Dorothy Milson, but my friends call me Milly. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were friends in school, so we call Strafe by his last name.
We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. Mrs. Malseed always smiles and welcomes us when we arrive. She seems to know when guests come. She tells the porter, Arthur, to take our bags to our rooms. The rooms are named after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers.
Mr. Malseed greets us with a big smile and says, "A hundred thousand welcomes!" Everyone is happy, and we feel our holiday has started. Nothing has changed at Glencorn, and everything is good. Kitty from the dining room comes to say hello. She tells us we look younger every year, and everyone laughs.
After dinner, we played cards for a little while because we were tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. Many people were at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is full in June. From our table, we could see some guests walking on the grass and others going down to the beach.
In the morning, we would walk on the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there. Then we would come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We liked this routine because we loved the beautiful landscape of Glencorn Lodge. 
---
**Questions:**
1. When do the friends go to Ireland?
2. What is the name of the house where they stay?
3. Who found Glencorn Lodge?
4. What are the names of the rooms?
5. What do they do after dinner?

Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She finished university last summer. She studied French and History of Art. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.
After breakfast, Sarah cleans the kitchen or makes afternoon tea for the guests. By 11 a.m., she goes skiing. She loves to ski and can stay on the slopes until 4:30 p.m. After skiing, she returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen.
Sometimes Sarah talks with the guests, and sometimes they want to be alone. She enjoys good guests because they make her week better. Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at night but do not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is a busy day.
On Sunday, Sarah starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. At around 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. 
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. Then, she gets a ride back to the chalet. After dinner, she sometimes has a drink, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore big clothes and had messy hair, but her face was pretty. Seymour was surprised that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research about leather in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
Sometimes, students called or wrote to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. He liked to help serious students by answering their questions or giving them a short tour. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who visited the factory years ago. Seymour showed them how to make gloves. He remembered how Marie loved to see the special table where the workers shaped the gloves with hot metal hands. Marie called them "pancake hands."
Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She wrote down the answers. She asked, "Do they come to your shipping department?" Seymour said, "No, they go to the tannery. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us. My family worked in the tannery. I worked there for six months too. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour said, "You should go if you want to write about leather. I can help you. The tannery is old and not very nice, but it is interesting. The first clothes were made from animal skins."
Seymour said, "My father knows a lot about leather. You should talk to him. He can talk for a long time about gloves. Do you know how things are made, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "Not really. I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. He liked her spirit and her desire to learn. 
Rita was much smaller than Marie, but she reminded him of her. Marie was always happy and remembered everything she learned in school. Seymour said, "We will show you how to make gloves. What size do you wear?" 
**Questions:**
1. Who is Miss Rita Cohen?
2. Where does Rita study?
3. What does Rita want to learn about?
4. What did Seymour show the children years ago?
5. What did Rita see her mother make when she was a child?
6. What will Seymour show Rita?

**Is it a hard job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as good as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. Raquel is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job but has one problem: she does not like flying. "On a long trip to California, I take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst trip was on Concorde. "It felt very small with tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork like organizing schedules and going to meetings. She did not apply for this job. She met a pop group manager by chance and took a secretarial course at night. Five years later, her boss needed a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy. A caddy carries a golfer's bags. He likes being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are some problems. He earns a small fee and a part of the winnings. He first caddied for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You do more than carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he says. Now, he works for European Tour Productions. He collects and analyzes golf statistics from the caddies. Many people want this information.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easy tasks is to try food in nice restaurants. He thinks expensive restaurants are okay for people who can pay. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave," he says. He started writing a food column because a friend asked him. At that time, he worked in advertising. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "I had to take a pay cut, but it was a chance to do what I love," he says. He still cooks at home and rides a bike to stay fit.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer. "Before that, I loved words, but I mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story about chickens and a fox. I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy. I work on them in the mornings. I do not wake up very early. After lunch, I type my notes on an old typewriter. I get many letters each week, and I enjoy answering them. Now, I have some help with this."

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building with two floors. Outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains. One afternoon, Michael and his friends went up the ladder to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge and looked at the lake.
Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down!" He jumped off the roof and fell into the sawdust. He rolled around and laughed. "I dare you all!" he shouted. He called them cowards and wanted them to jump too. The friends looked scared, but one by one, they jumped down and laughed.
They lay on the sawdust and told jokes. Then one friend said, "Let’s go up to the roof again and jump down." They were not very excited, but they went up again. They jumped off until only Michael was left. The others called, "Come on, Mike! What’s wrong?"
Michael wanted to jump, but he stayed on the edge of the roof. He felt nervous and smiled silly. He tried to count to ten and then jump, but he could not. The friends laughed at him and said, "You are a coward! We can’t wait all night!" When he did not jump, they started to leave.
Michael felt sad and looked at the ground. He stayed on the roof for a long time. The sun was getting bigger and bigger in the sky. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home.
Michael felt ashamed and got up slowly. He walked home and was late for dinner. His stepmother said, "You should be home on time. If not, you can stay out tonight." She was a kind woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair. But Michael did not listen. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want a new job go to a careers adviser. First, you write a short history of yourself. Then, you take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with suggestions for jobs and training.
I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test was like a school exam. I was with about ten people, and we answered questions quickly. I had to remember that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard. They asked me to find mistakes in names and numbers and to match shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was sad to see that I did not do well in science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse! But it was good to hear that I made the right choice for journalism.
Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a chance to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I did not know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of training in design," she said. She also thought about taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she used her skills and moved to a job in Public Relations. She said, "I think I would have found this job without Career Analysts, but they helped me see what I really wanted to do. I have sent six friends there, and they are all happy."
Some people feel they need help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and thought her job was boring. She said, "I did not know what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind." She took tests that showed she liked sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the fourth meeting, she decided to study geology. She said, "The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. I am much happier now."
But not everyone finds careers advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, 24, was a sales representative. She said, "I did not know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser might help me. I got many new ideas, but I did not like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of training. I did not learn anything new about myself. If I told a friend my story, they would give me the same advice."

Fun at the Dentist's**
If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a blue couch. Patients sit on the couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Many people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make the office a nice place. He does not wear a white coat because many people think white coats mean pain. He believes dental visits should be relaxing and fun.
Jerome uses new ideas to help people relax. He was the first dentist in Britain to use virtual-reality headsets. Patients wear these headsets during their check-up. They sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while he looks at their teeth. Then, the headset shows them a video of their mouth. Many patients like this part of their visit.
The office smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. The usual dentist smell can make people scared. I thought the nice smell in the office was very good.
Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, but he takes his work seriously. The relaxation ideas are important, but good treatment is the most important. He uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He says, "When you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too." He wants to change the way dentists work in Britain to be less formal.
One day, a patient comes in. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers tea, asks what video he wants to watch, and leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a nice beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

Chocolate and Its History**
Chocolate comes from South America. Now, it is a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter. They buy more chocolate at Easter than at any other time, except for Christmas.
A long time ago, the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans grew the cacao plant. This plant is found in warm places like Africa and South America. The cacao tree has big fruit with seeds inside. When the seeds are dried, they are called cacao beans. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. 
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water." This drink was special and had spices in it. The Spanish liked to add sugar and cinnamon to the drink. 
In the late 1600s, people in Europe started to drink chocolate in special places called chocolate houses. At first, people made the drink from solid chocolate. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten made chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate drinks.
In 1847, a company in Bristol made the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate. 
In the late 1800s, French companies sold a lot of chocolate in Britain. But then, Cadbury made the Dairy Milk bar in 1905. This chocolate bar became very popular because of good advertising.
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are trying new ideas to sell more chocolate, like making chocolate ice cream or drinks. 
Cacao farmers still have problems because the price of cocoa beans went down in the 1980s. Many small farmers had to stop working. So, when you eat chocolate, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is a master at making art from shells. He wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. 
Peter shows his work in his apartment. He asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring; he is very interesting and friendly. He has made many lovely things. He points to some shell decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them. I love them." Peter never planned to sell his work. Five years ago, some friends told him to have an exhibition. They said, "People should see your work!" They helped him talk to a gallery owner.
His first exhibition was in London, and 70% of his art was sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices for his art are high, around £2,000 for some pieces. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes his work is special, and one day, people will want it even more.
Peter wishes he had started making art earlier. He thinks he could have made even better things. Now, he feels a bit limited because he is older. But his work is very different from the common shell art you see in shops. He has a "miniature mind," which means he makes small, detailed art. He creates boxes with tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of beautiful flowers.
Peter uses different materials for his art. He uses cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He has a clear idea of what he wants to make, and he works hard to make it happen. 
Peter travels to many places to find beautiful shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He looks for shells on the beach. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures. He believes that many shells are broken by people walking on the beach. He thinks it is okay to collect shells that are empty. 
Peter's work is beautiful, and he loves what he does.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. 
One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist says Kira will be late. Jane feels worried. She thinks about bad things she has read about models. She wonders if Kira will come at all. 
But when Kira arrives, she is smiling and friendly. She is tall and pretty. Kira is not wearing expensive clothes. She has on a simple black dress and trainers. Kira's mother is with her. Kira's mother is proud of her daughter.
Kira became a model by chance. Her older sister told her to enter a model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent in some photos. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. This made her feel confident. She won the competition and got a job with a model agency in London.
Kira has two lives now: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too much of herself. Kira feels sad about this. She says, "I am still the same person. I am just more confident."
Being a model is busy. The agency can call her anytime for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends. But her friends understand. They do not complain.
Kira has a bright future. She is beautiful and talented. When Jane asks Kira what she would do if she were not a model, Kira says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

Father and son look for gold
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold, maybe 10,000 ounces. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding a lot of gold worth five million dollars.
Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find gold. We just need to dig a little more." They have worked hard to find gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. They looked at old mining books and chose a good place to dig.
They cleared the land, found some gold in the rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to work. They took samples of the earth and removed old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-metre hole. Now, they need more money. They spent their savings and need to find someone to give them £50,000 to dig deeper for the gold.
Chris said, "It looks hard to find a backer, but we have some people to contact." Last week, people in the valleys heard about the dig, and many became interested in gold. Dolgellau needs tourists, and people are hopeful. Peter Woolven, the manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it will bring more people here, but I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."
The gold industry in Wales has become smaller since the late 1880s when many people worked in many mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed a month ago. Now, more individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He is 70 years old and said, "Searching for gold is exciting. It is like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time." 
**Questions:**
1. Who are Terence and Chris Madden?
2. Where did they travel from and to?
3. How much gold do they think they can find?
4. What do they need to dig deeper?
5. What does Peter Woolven hope for if they find gold?

IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She teaches at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.
When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. Rachel dives three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside.
A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, Rachel can hit a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.
The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency. They tested how she would feel in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was dropping off equipment to study a project that would make a hole through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot.
Once, Rachel was scared when she dived with an American team. They were using equipment when there was a loud explosion. Rachel thought she would die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!
Diving to the bottom of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the window, she sees the chimneys of the volcanoes. She feels wonder because no one else has seen them. Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

"I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little tan. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. I was very tired. I could not understand any more train times, money, or languages. I said, 'Never again,' when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after. I just had to buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 
Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. Carrying my things in a backpack made me travel simply. I learned to throw away things I did not need, like old socks and books. This is part of the fun of Inter-Rail. With a ticket in my hand, I felt free. 
On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special this train ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra miles did not cost us anything. We were excited to travel. This was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw the things that were easy to find. 
I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We just wanted to enjoy our time. We shared the train floor, food, water, money, and music with other travelers. 
Traveling is exciting because you see places you only heard about before. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. You can only really know Europe by seeing it yourself. Everyone knows about it, but it is different when you see it. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this."

It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, you may be in a different place with different weather and have to wear clothes that are not right for that place.
Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes. It is hard for any airline to promise that your checked bags will go on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.
Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for bags to be checked and put on the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change planes. This time is often longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights. This can cause bags to be lost. Human mistakes can also happen, like if a bag label comes off.
Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because many bags are processed there. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, and many of them were changing planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow.
Even good airports like Amsterdam and Singapore can have bad days. Some airports, like Miami in the United States, are known for losing bags when passengers change planes quickly.
To avoid losing your bags, try to choose direct flights and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline. Allow more time to change planes by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to put your name and address on your bags, inside and outside. Don’t forget to write your flight numbers.
If your luggage is still missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report before you leave the airport.

The Kingfisher**
The kingfisher is a beautiful bird. It is blue and green. It lives near rivers and streams. The kingfisher eats fish. 
In the places where kingfishers live, there are old trees. These trees give some shade to the water. The colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sun. The sound of water is soft and nice. 
The kingfisher moves very fast. It looks like a flash of light. It is here for a moment and then it is gone. Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He loves kingfishers. He does not know why he loves them so much. 
There are stories about kingfishers. In Greek myths, a kingfisher is a bird that was once a moon goddess. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its body became blue like the sky. 
Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. They look blue because of how their feathers are made. The light makes them look blue or green. 
Charlie James has a strong passion for kingfishers. He likes to watch them from a hideout. His first hideout was an old blanket over his head. He waited near a place where kingfishers like to go. The bird came back very quickly and sat close to him. 
Charlie spent a lot of time by a stream with kingfishers. But he missed school because he wanted to be with the birds. He did not do well in school. At 16, he started working for a nature magazine. Later, he became a wildlife film cameraman. 
Now, Charlie wants to make a special film about kingfishers. He wants to show their beauty with pictures, not words. He loves to take photos of their wings. 
Charlie feels a strong connection to kingfishers. His photos show some of his feelings, but there is much more to his love for these birds.

Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. ANNE MANSON  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice in Vienna. She ended up helping him because an assistant was not there. She was not nervous when she took the first rehearsal. Anne is from America and works with a London opera company. She focuses on modern music. She has also worked in other European countries with help from the British Arts Council.
B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting good chances to work. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying two times before. He is happy it happened when it did. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. He hopes people will not only remember him for the competition. He is now working with the English Chamber Orchestra again.
C. WASFI KANI  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She loves the long practice time for opera. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional two years ago. She learned a lot from her teacher, Sian Edwards. Wasfi likes the complex nature of opera because there are many arguments and different personalities.
D. ROGER VIGNOLES  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says conducting surprised him, but he finds it very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina for the first time. He found it easier than he thought. He knows the music well and tries to get the best performance. He learns from all his experiences and is open to new opportunities.
E. WAYNE MARSHALL  
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed him and told his agent about him. Wayne soon had to conduct a musical in London with little notice. It was a tough start. Some musicians were not paying attention during the show. He was firm with them and tried to get the best result. Wayne has not studied conducting formally, but he is determined and knows what he likes.
---
**Questions:**
1. How old is Anne Manson?
2. What did Andrew Constantine win in 1991?
3. What does Wasfi Kani love about opera?
4. What did Roger Vignoles do for the first time last year?
5. Who noticed Wayne Marshall in 1986?

Fun at Theme Parks**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. Here are five families who visited some parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island would be boring, but it was fun! The park is good for younger children. Our three-year-old had a great time. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special ride for little kids, and they enjoyed it. For older kids, there are exciting rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, we were tired, but the kids wanted to stay. The park was clean and safe, and the staff were very helpful.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were excited. We thought Oscar was too young, but he loved it! He liked the Mountain Train and Little Land, where there are small models of famous buildings. The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We spent six hours there and found nice places to rest. The staff were friendly and helpful.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which was very exciting. We tried the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but said it was fun. Their favorite ride was Running River, which looked scary but wasn’t. For younger kids, Toy Land is very fun. The park is clean, and the staff are nice. One staff member helped me with one of my girls when I couldn’t sit with both.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We got to the park at one o'clock and were sad it closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger kids because the rides are not too scary. I am scared of rides, but I had fun. We loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that was exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn’t want to go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun. The kids loved the rides.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. The Rocket is the tallest roller-coaster in Europe, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down, was worse! There are many rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. Some staff were nice to the younger kids, but not all were friendly. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We didn’t want to tell the kids we were going home early.

Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside.
A. "My customers are friends," says Christine Hogan. She has a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted to work at home. I worked with computers before I got married. My husband said I should start a computer design business. It was hard at first and I needed a lot of money. I told the bank manager if I would spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. My business is small. People from the area come to pick up their work."
B. "I enjoy being independent," says Maggy Sasanow. She designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, and there were no jobs like that. So, I started my own business. I make 50 different greeting cards and sell them to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working from home is that there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I don’t advertise; people tell others about my work. I am cheaper than other artists. I work alone, so I don’t share ideas with others, but I like it more than not."
C. "It has been hard at times," says Delia Turner. She makes curtains. "I started my business eight years ago. At first, it was good, and my income grew from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. I had six workers, but I had to let them go because of money problems. It was hard to find new jobs for them. Now, I make curtains at home with my husband’s help and work with women who work from home. I have to lower my prices sometimes and look for new chances."
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, London was too expensive, and second, I love the countryside. I like to work when I want. Most of my money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I take calls at strange times. It is hard to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures and work with authors and artists. I felt alone at first because I worked in London before."
E. Meg Rivers runs a cake business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six workers, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I care about health, so I made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building. Now, we have a baker and an assistant. I don’t bake anymore; I manage the business. My biggest problem has been money because I did not have a lot to start."

Meet the Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is very special. They are all musicians. The dad, John, makes musical instruments. The sons, Paul and Huw, play music. 
John and Hetty are teachers in South Wales. They wanted to buy a cello for their son, Paul, who is ten years old. But the cello was very expensive. John thought, "I can make one!" He found a school where he could learn to make instruments. He took classes for three years. 
John made violins first. Then he made a cello for Paul. Paul liked it very much. John now makes about twelve violins every year. He even sold one to a famous musician from America!
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul learned to play the piano first. He wanted to play the cello because he thought the cellist in his dad's group was very cool. Huw also plays music, but he did not want to play the violin like Paul.
Huw said, "My parents were very nice. They did not push me to play music." Now, Huw is 22 years old and is a pianist and composer.
Paul is now a famous cellist. He won a big music competition and played in the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his dad's cello for a long time. Now, he has a very old cello on loan from a music school.
Paul will play on television soon. He will play a famous piece of music. But he cannot watch it because he is playing at a festival the same night. Huw will also perform in London that night. Their parents, John and Hetty, will be very busy trying to see both of their sons play music!

Looking after the Countryside**
**The National Trust**
The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to a warden from the Trust. 
Gareth Roberts is a National Trust Warden. He says, "You need common sense and you must be good with people." He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders every day. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted to be the warden, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area and has farming experience.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm. This helps him understand farmers and their problems. He can also do physical work like building fences and planting trees. Since he started working with the Trust, he has learned more about nature. When he was young, he liked to pick flowers and collect birds' nests. Now, he sees that farming has changed the countryside.
At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted different things. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job is to help finish projects and make sure everything is done well. He spends a lot of time writing reports and signing papers.
Gareth loves his job, especially talking to people. But sometimes, he finds some visitors rude. They come in, ask for things, and leave without saying thank you. This can be frustrating for him. 
If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But it may take a long time to find a job on the Lleyn Peninsula!

**The Netball Captain**
Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. I met her before the World Championships. She had a busy day. She taught at a school and then trained in a car park.
I asked her if people look at her when she trains. She said, "I focus on my training. I don’t see much else." Kendra is working hard to be ready for the Championships. This is her fourth time at the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing.
Kendra said, "We will have support from our home crowd. This is special." She wants people to see netball as a good sport in England. The first game is against Barbados. Kendra thinks they can win because they have always won before, but she knows it will be a tough game.
The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra said, "The Championships are hard. You must play well every day. There is no time to rest." In the last fifteen years, netball has become faster and more competitive. Kendra said, "We train hard to win, but after the game, we are friends."
Netball players now use science to help them train. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like the best players. As captain, she wants to support her team.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
What can parents do for a child who is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents may not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special help that regular schools may not provide. 
Specialist music schools can help these children. There are five music schools in Britain. These schools help children aged seven to eighteen to grow their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. 
At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, and learn about singing and music theory. They also practice in special rooms. The rest of their time is for important subjects like English, math, and science. 
The five music schools in Britain are independent, which means they are not run by the government. The classes are small, so teachers can pay more attention to each student. Most children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.
However, there are some problems. The schools are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year. The schools try to help parents with scholarships, which are financial aids. Also, not all parents want to send their children to live at school, especially when they are very young. 
The directors of the schools worry about admitting children as young as seven. They want to help children grow into well-balanced people. Sometimes, being in a music school can be stressful. A child’s musical talent may change as they grow up, and the pressure to succeed can be hard. 
The schools watch how each child is doing and offer help if needed. Many former students say they learned a lot from the music schools, but some think it is not good to focus only on music and not on other subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school. 
It might be better to wait until a child is older to decide on a specialist music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects can do well in regular schools with good music programs. Some music colleges offer lessons on Saturday mornings, but this may not be possible for families who live far away from big cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. She has a big garden around her house. This garden has many flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. There are two long flower beds along a path in the garden. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The people who lived there before Susan were good gardeners. They left many plants that Susan likes. She also has a gardener named Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint single flowers instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she picks flowers and takes them to her studio. She does not paint everything at once. She takes one flower, paints it for a few days, and then takes another flower. Sometimes it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. 
Spring and early summer are her busy times because the tulips and poppies bloom. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also likes to see how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape after a day. At first, they look boring, but then they become beautiful.
