Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She thought wild flowers were real because they grow in hard places, like rocks or cliffs.
Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they do not break anything. She has two art shows coming up, so she has less time to work in the garden. She now has another gardener to help her, but she knows that to paint flowers well, "you have to get your hands dirty." 
**Questions:**
1. What is Susan Shepherd known for?
2. What flowers does she like the most?
3. Who helps Susan in the garden?
4. How does Susan paint flowers?
5. Why does Susan think wild flowers are special?

Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She finished university last summer. She studied French and History of Art. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.
After breakfast, Sarah cleans the kitchen or makes afternoon tea for the guests. By 11 a.m., she goes skiing. She loves to ski and can stay on the slopes until 4:30 p.m. After skiing, she prepares dinner for the guests. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. 
Sometimes, Sarah talks with the guests, but sometimes they want to be alone. Good guests make her week better. Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at night but come home early on Saturday because Sunday is a busy day.
On Sunday, Sarah wakes up early to cook breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she cleans the chalet quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. 
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. Then, she gets ready for dinner again. Sometimes she is very tired and goes to bed early.

Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "It was hard to choose my clothes for Marie Claire because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to see some new clothes before lunch. The zoo is calm and quiet, but here I was busy. Some people on the fashion team looked stressed, but my job is not stressful. In the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean animal cages. I like to see how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I wore my leather boots and dark blue pants. The zoo gave me a green shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. When I touched an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was dirty but happy. When I stop working in fashion, I want to work with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team. Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes do not see the sun. It was hard work, but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I thought gardening would be easy, but it is hard work. I will not stop being a nurse."
Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would feel sick, but I was okay. The nurses are friendly, and it felt nice compared to my usual job. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but I felt good about it."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I wore the uniform, and I felt different. People looked at me. Before the flight, our boss told us about safety. I knew some of this from my training. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who were very noisy. I wished I was back in the gym."
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer. "I was nervous because I do not exercise. I was surprised at how much attention trainers give to one person. In my job, I meet many passengers every day. At lunch, I saw that some trainers do not eat very healthy food, but they drink a lot of water. I do not want to change jobs, but I want to join a gym and be healthier."

Train Memories**
Five famous people share their favorite train memories with Andrew Morgan.
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France. I go there when I can. There is a train from Cannes to Italy. The views are beautiful, no matter the weather. You can see nice houses and gardens. The people on the train are happy. There are tourists and locals, all enjoying the trip.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have many good train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to Kruger National Park. I was too young and stayed with my aunt. When I moved to England, I saw my first big train station, London Waterloo. It was amazing!
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
One special train for me is the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon in France. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. I love pink now! The journey was lovely, and we took a boat on the Nile after that. It was a perfect trip after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
I worked on a project about a trip around the world. We had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not good, and we waited a long time. When the train came, many people got on, even on the roof! At night, we saw beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Many people love trains from when they are kids, but I did not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where there were few trains. I started to love trains as a teenager when I made a film in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old train line. I loved riding the train, and when I visited last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights at the station!

Do you want to get your story published? If you are not sure where to send it, Margaret Stubbs can help you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or a book. Who can I send it to?" 
First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. It is important to know about the market for your writing. You can do this by reading a lot. Go to your local library and visit bookshops. Reading helps you understand what kind of stories publishers want. 
You should keep learning because new magazines and books come out all the time. Publishers always want new writers. If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish love stories. Get some recent copies and read them. This will help you know what kind of stories they like and who their readers are.
Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and ask, "This was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I try to give honest advice, but I also want to be positive. Many new writers are too quick to send their work out. If you have only written one story, it is very hard to get published. 
When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have worked in writing for a long time. When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten or twenty more stories. Each one will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. 
Do not throw your stories away; try to make them better. At first, do not show your work to others. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 
Try to improve your writing. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you cannot find one, join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and feel more confident. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**Text:**
On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were many people waiting. The station did not feel clean and nice like before. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and college students had their bags on the floor.
A man with grey hair was walking around. He looked rich. He went to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came to a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I would like to talk to her. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" The girl said, "I am going north, but not to Philadelphia. I am going to New York." The man thanked her and walked to the next bench.
Now I was watching him. He asked an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "I am going to Wilmington." He did not say anything and walked to a couple with matching bags. I moved closer, looking at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia. I thought he could have asked me, but he did not. He looked at me quickly and then went to another bench.
He looked worried. He asked a woman reading a book, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She was about thirty-five years old. She said, "Yes, I am." The man asked her for a favour. I stood a little away and looked at my wrist, even though I did not have a watch. The woman looked careful. The man said, "It is not too difficult, I promise!"
They announced my train. People started to move to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man said, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and went home. My wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and did not know what to do."
The woman listened. I thought it was better to stay quiet and see what would happen. The man said, "I told her to stay at the station. I will get someone to bring her passport." I thought it was strange. Why did he not go himself? The woman asked, "Why don’t you go yourself?" He said, "I can’t leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair." I thought this was not a good excuse.
I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a normal envelope, but a padded one. I thought, "Be careful, lady!"

Gary and Me**
John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had a chance to cook, and John had a chance to run a restaurant. When John saw the restaurant, it was not in good shape, but he thought it was perfect for him.
John remembers his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad when he was alone. He wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, to be confident. They talked to customers from a young age.
Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a bath and hurt himself. As he grew older, he did small jobs for money. By ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend and earned a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early. John liked to see Gary helping in the family business.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adult cooks and sometimes in charge. He made many meals. John knew Gary would work in catering. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Gary also started playing the drums and has his own band now. John told Gary to focus on one thing. He said, "If you want to succeed, do it by 30." Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished his work very quickly and helped others.
Now, Gary has a successful TV cooking show. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary to work hard for what he wants. John thinks that if Gary listened to even a little of his advice, it is good.

Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin is very hard. It is like looking for gold. The best way to find a flat is to know someone. If you know a person who knows someone else, you can find a place. But Jo just arrived in Dublin. She did not know anyone. She had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. 
Dublin was new and big for Jo. She felt nervous when she took the train to go there. She did not think about why she was going. Everyone at her school thought she would go to Dublin. They wanted to leave their small town and see new things. Some of her friends went to other towns, but Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo's mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. The hostel was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Jo's father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels can be cold. Jo's sisters worked in a hotel and thought it was crazy for Jo to stay in a hostel for a week.
Jo saw an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked. Jo thought it was too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice and not too expensive. 
There was no line for this flat. It was not just a flat for rent; it was looking for a third girl to share. Jo wondered if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf came down the stairs. 
"Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They are both awful." 
Jo asked, "What do you mean?" 
The girl said, "She just looked around and made a face. She talked in a posh accent. We don’t want her here." 
Jo met another girl named Pauline. Pauline had bright clothes and colorful hair. Jo thought she looked like a punk. Jo said, "I’m Jo. I work in the post office." 
Nessa, the girl with the college scarf, said they were going to have tea. She got three mugs. One mug had 'Nessa', one had 'Pauline', and one had 'Other' on it. "We will put your name on a mug if you stay with us," Nessa said kindly.

Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We like to see them in the sea, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds tells us about this problem. 
Dolphins are special animals. They are smart and can feel human emotions. They make us think of freedom in the ocean. We see dolphins in shows like Flipper and Seaquest. But these happy shows do not show the real life of dolphins. The seas are dirty and there are not enough fish for them.
In the North Sea, the number of harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down a lot. There are about 89,000 fewer porpoises now. You might think that dolphins are protected by law and live in safe places. This is not true. There are not enough plans to help them, and this could be a big problem for wildlife.
There are forty types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we see striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and smaller harbour porpoises. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We do not know much about them because we see them only in small groups. 
Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are friendly and were often seen in places like the Thames River in Britain. Now, we can only find them in a few places, like Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The dolphins that are still there have injuries, which show they are stressed.
It is hard to know why there are fewer dolphins. Overfishing is a big problem. When fishermen catch too many fish, dolphins cannot find food. If fish are gone from one area, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. 
In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall. They have marks and cuts on their bodies from fishing nets. 
Dolphins can also get sick from waste in the sea. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins can pass these poisons to their babies through their milk. There is one case of a baby dolphin that died because of this.
Another problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to communicate. Noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. This noise travels better in water than in air, and we do not know how it affects dolphins yet.

**Getting Fit**
Exercise is very important for your body and mind. It helps you feel good and stay healthy. Many people talk about fitness because it is good for you. 
Exercise can make your muscles stronger and change your body shape. It helps you stand and sit better. It can also help you avoid injuries. Exercise is good for your heart and lungs. 
Exercise can help with feelings of sadness and tiredness. It can help you sleep better and reduce stress. It can also help with some health problems. 
There are many types of exercise you can do, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But be careful! If you exercise too hard, you can get hurt. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are not sure what is good for you.
Good posture is important. It helps you look and feel better. If you slouch, try to imagine a balloon pulling you up. This can help you breathe better and look slimmer.
Stretching is also important. It helps your body move easily and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. 
A good exercise routine should include warming up, stretching, a workout, and cooling down.

IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for a long time? They want to find the best pictures of animals. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, in a place called the Ngorongoro Crater. It has rained a lot there for six months. This has caused some problems for them. Owen said they had to buy a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud.
Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films. One of their best films is about leopards. While people were watching this film, Amanda and Owen were already looking for another animal, the jackal. Film-makers like them travel all over the world to film animals.
I talked to Owen when he was at a safari lodge with other people. He said, "We sometimes argue, but we make up quickly." They do not think one of them is the boss. They both see animals in the same way. 
When they travel, they set up their tents every night. This time, they have a fixed camp. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Owen said, "We can be out for eight weeks, so cooking can be a little stressful."
It can be hard work, but they like being in nature. They can get close to the animals. Owen remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go away and then come back to greet her family and even their car.
Owen first worked with Amanda in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Now, they spend four months in one place to make enough material for a half-hour film. Before they start, they must show a script to get approval.
Owen said, "Amanda and I work well together because we have the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts."

**The Netball Captain**
Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. I met her before the World Championships. She had a busy day. She taught at a school and then trained in a car park. I asked her if people looked at her when she trained there. She said she was too focused on her training to notice.
Kendra said, "I want to be my best for the Championships." She has a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and many countries will play. She is happy to have support from home. She wants people to see netball as a good sport in England. There will be more pressure because they are playing at home. People want them to win their first game against Barbados.
The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra said the Championships will be hard. "You must work hard every day. There is no rest between games. You only have one chance to win," she explained. The game has become faster and tougher over the years. Kendra said, "We train hard to win, but after the game, we are friends."
Netball players now use science to help them train. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like the best players. As captain, she wants to support her team.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future. As she walks with her team in the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional. Her supporters will be with her.

In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She is a teacher at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.
When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. Rachel dives three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 
Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They are used to being in this small place. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem, Rachel can hit a panic button. This button makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.
The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot got sick. They wanted to see how she would feel in a small space.
Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was dropping off equipment to study a project that would make a hole through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot.
The only time Rachel was scared was when she dived with an American team. They were using a long rope when there was a loud explosion. Rachel thought she would die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the window, she sees the chimneys of the volcanoes. She feels wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen them before. Rachel studied black smokers for three years. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. People often make opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, how fast we talk, and our voice.
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to finish her studies. When she graduated, she felt confident. She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she did not want to be late. She believes it is important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not care about their appearance at an interview, how can they be a good teacher?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who look good at an interview are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big company. When her boss retired, she wanted to be the new boss but did not get an interview. She asked why and the Director said she did not look like an office manager. He told her to improve her clothes before applying again. Janet was surprised. She does a good job, and she thought her clothes should not matter.
How we move and use our hands can also change what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from our words, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and our face say different things, the listener will believe the facial expressions more. So, it is important that our words match our body language. Confusing messages can make the interviewer unsure.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went very well, and she got the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how happy she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have asked for more money if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of a job agency, says it is good to learn about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you what the company does. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you care about the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and using short sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long sentences. Good communicators use short sentences and clear points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. One day, he lost his job. He did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel. Now, he also sells meat by mail. He is happy to be out of the office, but he still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who helped him. Most people want to go back to work for money, but Ron did not. He and his wife moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but they still visit each other.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. She liked her job, but it was very busy. She did not want to work more hours, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but she did not. She has many deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier now, but she misses talking to other people at work. She likes being in charge of her work. If she does a bad job, she is the one to blame.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He worked in finance since he was 22 years old. He liked the excitement, but he did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to travel for a year. He wanted to find out what to do next. He liked health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He took courses in massage to learn. Now, he works part-time at the Life Centre. He is happy and feels in control of his life.

Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**
A. **Darius (Runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. Not many people heard about it, which was sad. I hoped to get some money for training, but it is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there, and I have to be very disciplined. If my friends want to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but I want to do well in my sport. My big goal is to go to the next Olympics.
B. **Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are in the morning. If I want to do well, I cannot go to late-night parties. I do not mind this, but I love to sleep in. I usually have to wake up early. It is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to celebrate, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on TV. Now, I am a bit famous.
C. **Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes, reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so I enjoy going out with my friends when I come back. You cannot only think about sports all the time; it is not healthy. People know me in sailing, but I am not very famous. I get letters from fans who want my picture, and I reply to every one.
D. **Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to play in front of a crowd. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many fans. I like being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But my last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. I focus on my game now and will think about other things in life when I retire, which is early in this sport.

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want everything they see. If it is not a new sugary cereal, it is a Disney video or a comic book. I cannot buy all these things. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to choose things."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on advertising for children, especially on TV. Children do not always understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents often talk about how sugar is bad for teeth, but children see fun ads and want the products.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat. They have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only listen to ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel bad because they have to say no to their children because of ads."
The rules for TV ads say that advertisers cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy things." 
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. One mother says she talks to her son about food and ads. She feels happy because he does not ask for things she does not want to buy. 
Some parents are not always consistent. Mike, a father, says, "We do not buy sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and children want to share that. But sometimes, I feel annoyed by their requests. If I am in a good mood, I say yes more often. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets can help parents by not putting sweets at the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less money if their children are not with them, but shopping without their children's demands could bring in more customers. 
**Questions:**
1. What do children often want when they go shopping with their parents?
2. How often do children ask for something in a supermarket?
3. What do parents think about sugary food?
4. What does Susan Dibb say about parents and children talking about food?
5. How can supermarkets help parents when they shop with children?

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has new technology to help both the staff and the guests.
Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. The hotel has a computer system to remember what guests like. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost a lot of money to install, but it will help the hotel save money in the future.
Guests can change the room temperature. They can set it between 14°C and 25°C. The hotel also has special technology in the rooms for business guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing system. 
The hotel is ready for new technology. They rent televisions so they can change them for new ones easily. The rooms are comfortable and welcoming. There are 145 bedrooms, a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food in the hotel is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud has a restaurant in the hotel. His restaurant already has two Michelin stars. He has made a new kitchen in the hotel. The Merrion Hotel is a great place to stay and eat.

Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann**: She is a journalist and author. She feels energy from excitement and challenges. Learning new things gives her energy. She is learning flamenco dancing now. Dance makes her feel good. If she is bored, she feels tired. Doing something useful gives her energy.
B. **Linda Kelsey**: She is a magazine editor. She has a lot of work, but she enjoys it. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. She needs a lot of sleep. When she sleeps six hours, she feels tired. Exercise gives her energy, but it is hard to find the energy to do it. She does yoga once a week and works out at home. When she exercises, she feels happy. In the afternoon, she feels low and thinks it is good to eat something.
C. **Annie Nightingale**: She is a disc jockey. She does not eat healthy food for energy. She thinks being positive gives her energy. She likes to enjoy life and have fun. She enjoys her work and likes to be around lively people. She loves taking photos and writing words for fun. 
D. **Floella Benjamin**: She is an author and a children’s TV presenter. She gets energy from doing things she enjoys. She believes being positive helps. She loves working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at people makes her feel good. She tries to eat healthy food and does not smoke or drink. She gets energy from playing with kids.
E. **Deborah Moggach**: She is an author and playwright. She loves making gardens. She once made a garden from concrete. It was better than exercise. Knowing that people want to read her writing gives her energy. She likes to explore nature, even if it is private land.
F. **Katherine Monblot**: She is a therapist. She believes you should care about what you do. She likes to take risks and gets bored easily. Doing things you don’t want to do makes you tired. She used to be in committees but did not like it. You should use your energy for what is important to you.
**Questions:**
1. What does Jeanette enjoy doing to get energy?
2. How does Linda feel when she sleeps six hours?
3. What does Annie think gives her energy?
4. Why does Floella like working with kids?
5. What does Deborah love to do with gardens?
6. What does Katherine think is important for energy?

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating is a fun activity that people have done for many years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, they made skates from iron. In the past, skating was important for rich people in Scandinavia. 
In the early 1900s, skating was very stylish. In 1924, a young girl named Sonja Henie made skating more popular by showing a new way to skate. Today, skating is both beautiful and hard work. 
For beginners, it is important to have balance and control. To skate well, you need to relax. When you start, your heels should be close together, and your feet should point outwards. Push with your back foot and move the other foot a little. If you practice, you can move longer and faster.
Learning how to fall is also important. Even good skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps you not to get hurt. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.
Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. It is best to start with figure skating. Many ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn.
Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should do exercises to warm up your body. This helps you not to get stiff. After skating, do the same exercises to feel better.
Skating helps you with balance and movement. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When you skate with swimming or jogging, it is great for your health!

'Winners and Their Stories'**
If you want to see something special, look at a child winning a medal. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.
A. Annika Reeder is 15 years old. She won a gold medal for gymnastics. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the Olympics. "I work very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV or go out with friends. I focus on gymnastics and school. Sometimes I feel very tired, and my coach gives me a day off, but I usually keep training. If I take too many days off, I feel stiff."
B. Annika's mother says, "Annika has always been very talented. Some parents push their children too much, but Annika wants to do this. It takes a lot of time and energy. People say we give up a lot, but we love the sport and what it does for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy, but now she is confident and has friends from all over the world."
C. Sarah Stokes started show-jumping when she was 10 years old. She has won the British National Championship. "My parents love show-jumping. They train me and take me to shows. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it. I love it! My goal this year is to join the British young riders team. I want to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. Sarah's mother says, "Sarah loved horses from a young age. When she was 5, she woke up early to exercise her pony. To go to big shows, we travel all over England. We sleep in our horse box to save money. Sarah is very organized and happy on a horse. It is wonderful to see your child succeed at something they love."
E. Jane McShane is 10 years old and is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it is fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate. I should, but I just look around. I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t want to feel embarrassed."
F. Jane's mother says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. I was bored when I learned, but Jane loved it. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves and started to beat adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wants to stop playing, that is okay. I want her to use her talent."

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Now, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.
Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were a long time ago. We are getting taller because we are eating better food now.
A long time ago, people ate many different foods. Women picked fruits and berries, and men hunted animals. They ate many wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed how people ate. Now, most people eat just three main plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This has not been good for our health. 
In one study, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became less healthy. They had more tooth problems and diseases. Farming could feed more people, but many of them were not healthy. Only in some rich countries like Europe, the US, and Japan are people starting to eat better again. 
Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but there are still problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less space for legs on planes and trains. 
Some scientists think we might stop growing taller soon. They say we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. But, even if some people are getting taller, as a group, humans might be getting smaller. A long time ago, during the ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we might be getting thinner and shorter. If the planet gets hotter, we could get even smaller. 
**Questions:**
1. How old was Chris Greener when he wanted to join the navy?
2. What is Chris Greener's height now?
3. What three plants do most people eat today?
4. In which countries are people starting to eat better food again?
5. What do scientists think about the height of humans in the future?

Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. 
Studio audiences are a common part of TV shows, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?" 
Some people think studio audiences are not important. They say that even TV workers do not respect them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different jobs and backgrounds. TV shows want different types of people for different shows.
Many people at home do not understand why anyone would want to watch a show in a studio. Why would someone get tickets, travel far, and sit for a long time in a studio? One reason is that people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on TV." 
Another reason is that people want to see how a show is made. But many people go because a friend gave them a ticket. 
Most of us have not been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH. You clap or laugh when you see these signs. This is true for some shows, but not all. 
One studio manager said, "We think a show should be good enough not to need these signs." But is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." 
What I missed was seeing the actors. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from where I sat, so I watched the show on a monitor. 
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but for most people, it was fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**
**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I like nice villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to the village of Lastingham. Cycling was fun for me. I loved to explore the hills and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first travel writing.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The view is not amazing. The train goes over Romney Marsh with sheep and next to a canal. But I like one part of the journey. The train goes through back gardens. For a moment, I see people making tea, washing dishes, and unfolding chairs. I feel like I am looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape with fields, sheep, and a grey sea. It makes me look closely at everything.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. Some surfers come, but most visitors just enjoy the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and has many shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips into beautiful valleys with oak trees and wild flowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open area that is great for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is quiet and empty, and I like the space. I found this place by chance when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, sometimes with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and villages. There was a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you would never come back. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

A Big Snake**
We love animals. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals. I was late getting home. I put a pot on the stove. Suddenly, I heard my son scream, "Oh, Mother! Help!" I ran to his room. 
In the room, there was a problem. Our cat, Domino, had Bianca, a white mouse. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth. I tried to help, but I tripped and fell. Then, I saw the snake. It was escaping! The snake was moving off the table and onto the floor. 
Domino, the cat, and the kids were jumping and screaming. The snake was moving fast. The dog was barking. The pot on the stove boiled over. I ran to turn it off. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. 
I looked at the snake. It was big and strong. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake relaxed. I carefully picked it up and took it to the garden. I wanted to let it go. I pointed the snake to a tree. 
When I let go of the snake, it climbed up my shoulders! It felt like a warm scarf. My children and I stood together. My oldest son said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." I asked the kids to help me. We gently encouraged the snake to move. 
Slowly, the snake went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. My three-year-old son said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"

"Write to me! In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is not common anymore. But I love getting letters. It is exciting to see a letter come, to see who it is from, and to read it. I have written letters for a long time. I started with little notes to my mother. My mother always made me write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.
When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote to me too. Sometimes my father wrote letters, and I loved his funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday things with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.
I also got letters from my boyfriends. They had to work or study far away, so we wrote letters to stay in touch. Writing letters helped our relationships. I could say what I felt better in a letter than by talking. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but letters with news are better! I like getting letters from other countries too. I have a friend in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. Now we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her because she does not speak English. She has visited us, and we have stayed at her home.
This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We wrote to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. My children also write letters. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas too. I hope everyone keeps writing letters!"

Tourists are hurting old rock art in the French Alps. There are many ancient pictures on the rocks at Mont Bego. These pictures are about 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and gods. Scientists are worried that these pictures will not last for future generations.
More and more people visit Mont Bego, but some do not care for the art. They write on the rocks and damage the pictures. Jean Clottes, a leader in rock art, says, "People think the pictures will always be there. But if this continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and hurting them. Some people even take pieces of the rocks home as souvenirs. 
Some visitors try to make the pictures look better by rubbing them. They think this will help them take better photos. Other people bring sticks to scratch their names or drawings on the rocks. 
Experts have different ideas on how to protect the art. Henry de Lumley, a museum director, thinks the best way is to close the mountain to the public. He believes this will save the site. But Jean Clottes thinks this idea will upset local people. 
David Lavergne, an architect, wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop visitors from damaging the rocks. He thinks they may need to charge money to visit the site to pay for guards. 
Annie Echassoux, a researcher, is worried that more tourists will come because it is easier to reach the mountain now. She believes they should block off some areas and have guides. She says, "We need money to protect this historic site. If we do nothing, we will lose the drawings for the next generation." 
**Questions:**
1. Where is Mont Bego located?
2. How old are the pictures on the rocks?
3. What do the pictures show?
4. What does Jean Clottes say about the future of the pictures?
5. What do some tourists do to the drawings?
6. What is Henry de Lumley's idea to protect the site?
7. Why does David Lavergne think they may need to charge money?
8. What does Annie Echassoux want to do to protect the area?

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want everything they see. If it is not a new sugary cereal, it is a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I cannot buy all these things. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I feel stuck."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes when they go shopping. A lot of money is spent on advertising for children, especially on TV. This makes it hard for parents to explain why they cannot buy certain things. Children do not always understand why their parents say no, especially when they see fun ads on TV.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat. They want to give them healthy food, but they do not always know what is healthy. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only listen to ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel bad because they have to say no to their children because of ads."
The rules for TV ads say that advertisers cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy things. So, even if they do not say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. One mother says she talks to her children about food, and now they do not ask for things she does not want to buy. Another father, Mike, says, "We do not buy sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy treats for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and children want to enjoy that too. But sometimes, I get annoyed with their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am happy, I say yes more often. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets can help parents by moving sweets away from the checkout area or by having play areas for children. Parents might buy less if their children are not with them, but shopping without their children's demands could bring in more customers.

Climbing Walls**
Climbers used to go to the mountains. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is excited. High on the climbing wall, the French climber Francois Lombard is hanging upside down by two fingers. He is in a climbing competition in Birmingham.
The place is called the National Indoor Arena. It is known for the TV show Gladiators, but it also has climbing competitions. This is possible because of new technology.
Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather or climb on snow and ice. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When they could not use cliffs, they climbed on brick walls or buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong.
Many sports centers started to build climbing walls. These walls had special bricks to hold on to. A teacher named Don Robinson built a climbing wall in a hallway at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock in concrete to make climbing walls.
In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built, but they had problems. The walls were straight, but cliffs have different shapes. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed. Climbers got bored because the walls were the same.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material. He made shapes like those on cliffs. These shapes could be put on any wall and taken off when climbers wanted something new. French companies also made climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could make different shapes. This gave climbers many new ways to climb.

'Do You Want to Be an Actor?'**
Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is risky. Acting can be a risky job. There are many actors, but not many jobs for them. When you choose to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy. But everyone has different opinions. It is your choice, and you are responsible for it. 
There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take tests, and there is no guarantee you will get a job after training. Success depends on luck and talent. There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.
What is talent? Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on your courage and belief in yourself. 
Why do you want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important thing is the moment between the actor and the audience. This moment is what makes actors want to perform.
If you ask actors how they succeed, they may not know. They understand some things about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they must keep working hard because their fame can change. 
Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been without a job. You could be selling clothes or working in a restaurant. Then, you may get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job, you might not get it. 
Actors often do not talk about their chances of getting a job. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and rejection. No one likes to be rejected. This possibility is there from the start when you want to be a professional actor. You are saying you are ready and talented enough for the job. If you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We have a special selection of the best cookbooks for you.
A. Delia Smith is a famous TV cook and writer. She has recipes from many places in the world. Her recipes are easy to follow and good for everyone. Her best book is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book helps you learn to cook. It has many simple recipes that are not boring. People say, "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?" This is the book!
B. Raymond Blanc is a chef from France. He worked for 15 years to become the owner of a famous restaurant in Britain. He has a TV show called "Blanc Mange" and a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone cook better. He explains how ingredients work together. His book has over 80 great recipes. It also tells you why some dishes can go wrong. He loves to cook for others, and he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a famous cooking school in France. For 100 years, they have taught many students to cook well. To celebrate their anniversary, they made a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." This book has 100 classic recipes. The recipes are still fresh and tasty. The book starts with basic cooking tips, then has sections for Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has pictures to help you. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools share their famous recipes in this book.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, a food editor, thinks differently. His new book is called "The 30-Minute Cook." He believes you can make tasty food quickly. In this book, you will find recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written more than 200 recipes from around the world. He shows that fast food can be great food. Try his recipes; they are delicious!

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Now, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.
Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were a long time ago. We are getting taller because we are eating better food now.
A long time ago, people ate many different foods. Women picked fruits and berries, and men hunted animals. They ate many wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed how people ate. Now, most people eat just three main plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This has not been good for our health. 
In one study, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became less healthy. They had more tooth problems and diseases. Farming could feed more people, but many of them were not healthy. Only recently have some rich countries started to eat better again. 
Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but there are still problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less space for legs on planes and trains. 
Some scientists think we might stop growing taller soon. They say we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. But there is a problem. Even if some people are getting taller, as a group, we might be getting shorter. A long time ago, people were rounder and taller because of the cold weather. Now that the weather is warmer, we are getting thinner and shorter. If the planet keeps getting warmer, we might get even shorter. 
**Questions:**
1. How tall is Chris Greener?
2. What did Chris want to be when he grew up?
3. What three plants do most people eat today?
4. What is the average height of a man in the US?
5. What problem do people face with beds and planes?

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. One day, he lost his job. He did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel. Now, he also sells meat by mail. He is happy to be out of the office, but he still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who helped him. Most people want to go back to work for money, but Ron did not. He and his wife moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but they still visit each other.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. She liked her job as a lawyer, but it was very busy. She did not want to work more hours, so she left. Some people said she would get bored, but she did not. She has many deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier now, but she misses talking to other people at work. She likes being in charge of her work. If she does a bad job, she is the one to blame.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He worked in finance since he was 22 years old. He liked the excitement, but he did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to travel for a year. He wanted to find out what to do next. He liked health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He took courses in massage to learn. Now, he works part-time at the Life Centre. He is happy and feels in control of his life.

**A Fun Game**
Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are in their forties and have big beards. They are playing a game called pichenotte. This game is special to them because their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought it from Canada. The family played this game every weekend and had a lot of fun.
When the family moved to New Mexico, they still played pichenotte. Their grandfather made the game board from old wooden boxes. When visitors came, they were curious because no one knew this game in the southern USA.
Three years ago, Dave made a new pichenotte board because the old one was broken. His family and friends liked it. One night, Dave and Norm took the new board to a sports bar. At first, people thought it was silly, but soon they wanted to play!
Dave learned that pichenotte comes from a game in India called 'carroms.' This game changed over time and became pichenotte in Quebec, Canada. Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces called 'pucks.' They flick the pucks into holes on the board to score points. The game is quick and usually lasts two minutes.
When many people liked the game at the bar, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets. Many people came to buy them, and soon there were pichenotte championships with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup.' The brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They work in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is strong and weighs 12 kg.
The boards cost $595 each and can be bought from their website. There are no professional pichenotte players yet, but the brothers hope to make a lot of money from their game. For now, they enjoy playing pichenotte together. 
---
**Questions:**
1. What are the names of the two brothers?
2. Where do they live?
3. What game do they play?
4. Who brought the game to the family?
5. How many pieces does each player have?
6. How long does a game usually last?
7. How many boards have they made?
8. How much does one board cost?

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you come to the Model Village, you will see a beautiful place. A few years ago, this land was not nice. It was flat and full of weeds. One man and his wife worked hard to change this land into the village you see today.
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to make the land look nice. Machines helped, but many people also worked hard. They brought in 1,000 tons of good soil to make grass, flowers, and rocks.
In the Model Village, many trees and plants were planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they need to grow well near the sea. Some plants came from local shops, and some came from far away places like Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims had the idea for the village. He made over 100 models by himself. It took him nine years to finish them. The models are made from stone, concrete, wood, and plastic. They are strong and can handle all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts, but soon he learned how to do it himself.
The models are very detailed and look real. The Model Village is popular and well-made. Other model villages in England use the same techniques.
The buildings in the village show traditional British styles. One important building is the Manor House. It is a 13th-century stone house with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course.
Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. If you touch them, it can take a long time to fix them. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
You can press buttons in front of some models to make them work. At the end of your visit, we would like to hear your thoughts. We are always making new models and want to know what you think. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures of famous people. These pictures often invade their privacy. Sometimes, pop stars take pictures with paparazzi, but this is not common. Most of the time, these pictures hurt the famous people when they see their private moments in the newspapers. Very few famous people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC). This group helps with problems like this. 
Are these pictures important for the public? For example, does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help anyone? The actress has talked about her privacy before. She was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, but she did not complain. It is surprising that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
There was also a story about a pop star's love life that was very bad. The pop star did not make a formal complaint either. Shouldn't the PCC do something about this? If they did, it could help stop bad stories in the newspapers. Other newspapers would talk about it, and people would not like these stories. 
But if the PCC became like a police officer for the press, there would be problems. How would they decide to investigate? Should they ask the famous person if they want to complain? If the person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Famous people might expect help, but they could be upset if they do not get it. 
The PCC would have a big job. How could they watch all the newspapers and magazines in Britain? Also, people might not want to have an investigation because it could be embarrassing. Many famous people just want to forget about the problem and continue with their lives. Some might be afraid that a worse story about them could come out if they complain. 
One British comedian and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then or later when a photographer took pictures of his family on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would make fun of him. This fear is normal. People think they will be targeted again if they complain. It is hard to find an easy solution to this problem. 
**Questions:**
1. What do British tabloid newspapers show every week?
2. Do pop stars often take pictures with paparazzi?
3. What does the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) do?
4. Why did the actress not complain about the picture taken in the hotel?
5. What might happen if the PCC investigates the newspapers?
6. Why might famous people not want an investigation?

Many people give advice to new college graduates who are starting their first job. This article talks about getting a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one. We also do not talk about people who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. 
This is for those who want to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and know what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to focus on one area, get a higher position, or try something new. 
You should choose your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. 
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and find your second job later. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are ready to work.
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because the people were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. But there was no chance to move up in the job. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has changed." Her boss wanted to help her grow. Juliette's job title is the same, but her tasks have changed. She now does most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from important people and helps those who want to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects to do.

**Confident People: What is Their Secret?**
Confident people seem to be born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was scared, but I did well. Someone said I should go to university. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, I need to believe in myself. If work is too hard, I don’t feel guilty if I wait until the next day to finish. When things are difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to feel better.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am confident, but I often feel scared. I learned to look confident because it is important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. My mother gave me good advice when I was a teenager. She said, “Who is looking at you? Everyone is busy worrying about themselves.” I remember this often. I also think you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared.
**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work. I have built my confidence over the years. If you work hard and learn from mistakes, you will be more confident next time. I am popular at my restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don’t let that bother me. You must like yourself for who you are. My company has training courses that help me feel better about myself. It is good to set small goals and see what you achieve.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary. I sat in meetings and was scared to speak. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my ideas. When I started working in politics, I was very nervous to speak in public. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day.” I also wrote down some notes to help me. I think everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to tell yourself, “Nothing is impossible.” 
---
**Questions:**
1. What did Jenny do when she was twenty-five?
2. Why was Michaela scared when she took over the family business?
3. What advice did Lisa's mother give her?
4. How does Barbara feel about her work?
5. What did Kim do to help her feel less nervous when speaking in public?

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite festival. He spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiles when Paul gives him his broken kite. "You keep it," he says. "It is traditional. If the line breaks, the finder keeps it. I have many more kites." He shows Paul his beautiful kites. They are all the same size: 120 cm wide and long. They are made of paper and bamboo. 
Paul and Adnan sit in the shade of the trees near the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan. They watch Malaysia's biggest kite festival. There are 10 platforms on the beach. Helpers hold up the kites. Competitors hold the lines of their kites and wait for the countdown. When the whistle blows, the crowd cheers, and the kites fly into the sky. More than 500 men and boys are in the competition. Each person has four kites. The kites are judged on how they look, how stable they are in the air, and how well they fly. 
"Flying kites is not hard," says Adnan. "But making them is a real skill. Come to my house, and I will show you." Paul decides to go to Adnan's house. There, he drinks cold tea and eats fish crackers. In the evening, Adnan asks Paul to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but Paul cannot. Instead, he drives to Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with rainforests. 
Paul takes a wrong turn and finds a river. A small boat is there to take people across. He sees a sign that says, "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." He starts walking but does not know that it is mostly uphill and slippery. When he arrives, he meets Baba, who has a kitchen and some bamboo huts. Paul decides to stay there, even though he worries about insects under his mattress. 
At night, it is very dark, and he hears many sounds. In the morning, he sees a beautiful view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rains. The wind blows, and there is lightning. Paul gets wet. He slides down the hill and thinks about his car. He worries it might be washed away. Luckily, the car is still there, muddy but safe. 
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, people ask Paul many questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" They are friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but Paul remembers it for the kindness of the people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping. There are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? 
A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
I love shopping! I spend a lot of money. When I have money, I go shopping. I like sales. My boyfriend likes shopping too, so we go together. 
B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
I don’t like shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my son and daughter shopping for clothes, but I don’t enjoy it. I don’t buy clothes for myself often, and when I do, I feel guilty. 
C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
I only shop for what I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. I know what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired. 
D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want. I don’t waste time. I sometimes buy things I don’t need, so I am careful but make mistakes. 
E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
I really don’t like shopping. I can’t find what I want. The shops are noisy and messy. I don’t shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. I go food shopping once a week and do it quickly. 
F. Lisa, 22, actress

**MONEY**
What is money? Money is things like the pound, the dollar, or the franc. Money is different from a gram or a kilometre because you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.
A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, gave corn to Mr. Hive for honey. This was a trade between two people. Each person had something the other wanted.
Over time, many societies made their own money, called "currencies," so people could trade more easily. Now, most people use a national currency.

'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST
Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the first woman scientist in history. Hypatia's father was the head of Alexandria University. He wanted her to have a good education. This was special because most women could not study at that time. 
Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then, she went back to Alexandria and started teaching math. She became famous for her knowledge. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important math works. Hypatia also liked technology and made tools for her work.
At that time, many leaders were afraid of science. People who studied science were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'
