Grass**
Grass is a very successful plant. There are more than 9,000 types of grass. You can find grass in every part of the world. Grass can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. 
Grasslands are home to many animals. There are small insects and birds, and also big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to live. 
Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or hurt. New leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again.

Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She just won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. When she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and make designs. She did not tell her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to work in fashion. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she went to university to study management.
After university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising company. She went to many events but could not buy the nice clothes she wanted. So, she started to make skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. 
Kal found a small shop in London that would sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none came back. This made her happy and gave her the courage to leave her job. She took a loan of £20,000 to start her own women’s clothing brand. 
Kal's parents were not angry about her choice. They said they would help her, and this made her very happy. Now, her clothes are in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, and she designs for pop stars. She feels very lucky. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But I have worked hard for this."

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? 
Bo is a little cat. One day, she goes into a big van. The van is for furniture. The driver does not see her. He drives a long way, over 500 kilometers. At the end of the day, the driver is hungry. He finds Bo in the van. 
The driver gives Bo some milk. He wants to find her owner. He calls his last customers, but they do not have a lost cat. It is late, so he takes Bo home for the night.

Mark Ottaway took a train called The Ghan. He traveled from Darwin in the north of Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cooler south. Many people call it the "famous Ghan," but it is often late.
In the 1920s, there was a train line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. Sometimes, floods made it hard for trains to go. A new train line was finished before Mark's trip. The Ghan train is not very fast, and it has few stops. Most people on the train are on holiday. The food on the train is very good.
The train was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods by train from Darwin to the south would save time and money. The Ghan is the first train in the world to go north to south across a continent.
When Mark waited to get on the Ghan, he saw that everyone was excited. Many older Australians were ready to board. The first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some people got off to take a boat trip. Mark stayed on the train until Alice Springs. There, he went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. Climbing the rock is not popular now, so they just walked around it and watched the sunset.
From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south. Many people stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, they reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. Mark's journey was over. The train may not have done everything the ads said, but it took him to some amazing places in Australia. 
**Questions:**
1. Where did Mark start his train journey?
2. What is the name of the train Mark took?
3. Why is the Ghan train often late?
4. What did Mark see at Alice Springs?
5. What did Mark and his group do at Uluru?

Climbing Ben Nevis**
Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is the highest mountain in Britain. The weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first climb on Ben Nevis.
It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 metres high. We planned to camp for three days in a place called the 'Carries'. The 'Carries' are big bowls in the mountain, halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is very hard, like ice.
Even though some people in my group were very good climbers, we took safety equipment. We had lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, but I still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always hard.
The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest climber, so I had to rest more often. The others stopped to wait for me, but when I caught up, they started again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb.
After climbing 200 metres, we reached Tower Ridge. It is very narrow, only 1.5 metres wide, and the mountain drops down a lot on both sides. We had to stay calm and focus on every step as we walked slowly.
After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. But it was misty when we got to the top. 
Going back down to camp can be hard too. You need to read a map well. A wrong turn can be dangerous in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. When I was safe in the tent, I could finally say I enjoyed the climb. But I was proud that I made it to the top!

**Anna's New School**
This week is very exciting! We moved to our new school building. It is a great place. The builders used wood to make it, like our old school. This new school is also good for the environment. 
The school took a long time to build. We watched the builders work. It was exciting to see them clear the land, but some nice land went away. The building machines were very loud. Sometimes, the builders had to stop because it rained a lot. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the old school next door. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use the changing rooms when the new sports field is ready.
When you come into the school, you will see that there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat inside. It also keeps the sound inside, so when we sing, it feels like a concert hall!
You will also see a tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it. It goes around very fast and is very big!
We took pictures to put on the website. We are already using the school, but some parts are not finished. We are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to the old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year.
We are very happy with our new school! Our teachers say we will learn better here!

A Fun Weekend**
A month ago, I did not know that I would be climbing high in the air on a Saturday in November. Now, I look down at the river below me and understand why people like rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place was not very nice, but we had beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.
On Saturday morning, we met ten other people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.
Half of us went caving in the morning, and the others went rock climbing. Then we changed activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. **Letter to the Newport Evening News**
On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. In my handbag were my cheque book, address book, and my purse. My purse had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I lost my handbag, it was too late. I was 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the road and cried.
A young man asked me what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely. 
Soon after, the telephone rang. It was the manager of CityBus. He said they found my handbag and would bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, and everything was inside and safe. 
I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I appreciate their kindness and honesty.
Mrs. B. James, Newport

'Joining the Kirov Ballet
My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students at the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they talked to me in English. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers.
For the first two weeks, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a little sad. I even called her at night because I felt lonely. The ballet classes in Russia are harder than in England. I eat a lot to have energy. This helps me do well in class.
In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I feel at home, I like to walk around the city and visit the shops. In December, it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time!
Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**
The Arctic is a cold place. In summer, many people visit to see the midnight sun. In winter, there are not many people. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a special igloo in Jukkasjarvi. This igloo was on the frozen Torne River. Many visitors came to see it.
One night, some guests decided to sleep in the igloo. They liked it very much. This is how the idea of the ICEHOTEL started. Now, it is famous all over the world. 
Every winter, a team of builders and artists come to Jukkasjarvi to make the hotel. They use snow and ice. The first part of the hotel is ready in December. Each week, a new part opens until January 7th when the hotel is finished. The hotel is outside, so it can change depending on the weather. 
In spring, when it gets warm, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, it is never warmer than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves when they stay at the hotel. It is also good to bring sweaters, scarves, and thick socks. 
If you want to visit the ICEHOTEL, you can buy warm clothes on their website. They will bring the clothes to your room when you arrive. The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It is 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Shopping for Furniture**
A report by Dave Worthington
Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people came to the shop. There were special offers. A leather sofa was on sale for £45, but only until 3 am. A bed was £30, but only from 3 am to 8 am. 
The shop's normal hours are from 9 am to 9 pm every day. Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours. But it had to close after only half an hour. 
A police officer said, "We knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside were angry. They thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait in line. 
There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.
One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. It was not safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I do not want to wait in line again."

Membership**

Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can see articles from recent issues on our website.
**National Short Story Competition**
We have a big competition called the National Short Story Competition. Anyone aged 18 and older can enter. You can write about any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words. Members of the Society do not pay to enter, but non-members pay £5. The competition is from April to October each year. The ten best stories will be in our annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.
**Education**
For almost thirty years, the Society has helped writers in schools. We give children and teachers new ideas and help them feel good about their writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.
**The Writers' Cafe**
The Writers' Cafe is a nice place for members. It has vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. You can read our magazines there. The Cafe also has exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm on weekdays and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturdays. Members get discounts on some products and events.
**Becoming a Member**
We have members all over the world. Anyone aged 18 and older can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.

Free-diving in the Caribbean**
Tanya Streeter is a free-diver. She has four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and come back up without help. She held her breath for more than three and a half minutes. This made her the only woman to break a man’s world record in any sport.
A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is dangerous, but Tanya believes safety is very important. She also thinks training is important. Most free-divers focus on one or two events, but Tanya trains the same way for all her events. 
She spends two-thirds of her training in the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she does not want to hurt her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. 
When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She tries to do fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important for her to not get tired.
When Tanya is not training, she talks to people about sports and helps environmental groups. She grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring the sea. Tanya says her life now is like her childhood dreams. Because she is famous in some countries, people listen to her about environmental issues.
In the future, Tanya wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving when she was twenty-five years old, so she does not plan to stop for many years.

**CARTOON FILMS**
Cartoon films can be very fun. If you can draw, you can make your drawings move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons exciting for everyone. 
In the late 1970s, many people thought cartoons were only for kids. But some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids can enjoy cartoons together. 
Not all cartoon films were good. For example, "The Black Cauldron" was not successful. It was too scary for kids and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this, and soon, cartoon films made a lot of money again.

Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role**
Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first job on TV. 
"I did not think I would be on TV in my first year at university. I only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book 'The Finnegans' since I was eleven years old. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I wanted to play her.
I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She said they wanted to make the book into a TV show. I wanted to try for the part. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director. She asked him to meet me. I flew back home and got the part!
Filming started a week after university began. I asked the university for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to write my essays. I did not tell my friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel very lucky.
After university, I want to be an actor. My family is not in acting, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I have not received any offers yet. I had a busy social life too. When filming finished, I did not know what to do. I have acted in two college plays since then. 
I have not been home much, and now my first year at university is over. I am going to Greece for the summer with my friends."

**Text:**
In 1976, I opened the first 'Body Shop'. I wanted to earn money to feed my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' is a big company in many countries. I have learned a lot since we started. I want to share what I learned in this book. 
This book is not just about my life or a normal business book. It is about being different to succeed in business. Business can be fun. It can be run with love and can help people. 
In business and in life, I want to enjoy myself and feel like a family. I want the people who work at 'The Body Shop' to feel this way too. This book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and what we can do. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too. 
**Questions:**
1. When did the author open the first 'Body Shop'?
2. What did the author want to earn money for?
3. Is 'The Body Shop' a small or big company now?
4. What does the author want to share in the book?
5. How does the author want the people who work at 'The Body Shop' to feel?

**A Journey on the Douro River**
Jules Verne has a special ship called the MV Lady Ivy May. This ship travels on the Douro River in Portugal. It can take 160 guests. All the rooms have a view outside and have a shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning. On the ship, you can find a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.
**Itinerary**
**Day 1:** You will fly from London Heathrow to Oporto in the evening. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May. You will sleep on the ship.
**Day 2:** In the morning, you will see Oporto. After that, you will go back to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the trip takes four hours.
**Day 3:** You will keep traveling up the river. In the evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where they make port wine. At dinner, you can try the local food and drink.
**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will take a bus to Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings and sculptures. Then, you will go back to the ship and sail to Tua.
**Day 5:** The river becomes narrow here. If the water is deep enough, you can take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by bus and see many things on the way.
**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. You will have lunch on the ship and then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.
**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before going back to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the ship.
**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with time to see the city and shop before your flight back to London Heathrow.

HONEY**
Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugar. Bees can fly very far, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit many flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter honey is usually sweeter than darker honey.
A long time ago, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was hard to find. The ancient Egyptians valued honey and used it as money. Today, people all over the world make and eat honey. Some studies say honey can help with tiredness and make you better at sports. Honey is not just food; it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair products.

Norwich**
Norwich is a city in East Anglia, England. It has been a place to live for more than 2,000 years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. In 1066, when the Normans came, it was one of the biggest towns in England. 
Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years as a city. This means it could govern itself. 
Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester. It has about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second city in England. For 300 years, it grew and became rich. It was famous for many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs. 
In 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a busy place for business. It has theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. There is also a football team called 'The Canaries'. Their colours are green and yellow.
Norwich has a new shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, builders worked on it. They made a park on the roof with water pools and trees. The old market is still there, and people are happy about it. Norwich has a nice mix of old and new things.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**
Every autumn, the sky in Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, is full of bright colours. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival. It is a nine-day event every year. The first festival was in 1972 for the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a car park in Albuquerque. Now, many balloons come from many countries.
**What to See**
The pilots talk to each other on radios. They light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This is called a "balloon glow." It is a great time to take photos. You should come just after night falls or before 5:30 am to see the "glows" as the balloons go up into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are in many sizes and colours. Some look like animals or cartoon characters, and some look like popular drinks and fast food. Kids will love it!
In the afternoon, you can fly in a balloon over the desert with one of the companies that offer balloon rides. You can also take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride, and you can see the festival from above. There are many other fun things to do, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.
**The Albuquerque Box**
This is a special wind pattern that helps balloon pilots. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This helps pilots control their balloons by going up or down.
**Practical Advice**
Buy your tickets early online to avoid waiting in line. Wear several layers of thin clothes. It can be cool at night and in the morning, but during the day, you need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and don’t forget your camera. If you use film, bring high-speed film for night pictures.

**The Eden Project**
The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists. The big 'biospheres' look like something from a science fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. It shows how important plants are for people.
Many things we use every day come from plants. For example, we get wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate from plants. There are more than 135,000 types of plants here.
Even if it is cold outside, the plants stay warm. There are electric heaters that keep the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. There is also a zone that looks like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. Soon, they will build a desert zone too.

'No Title
Some people do not like this year's book, New Writing 3. I do not understand why. It has 500 pages of good writing for £6.99. Most of the book is fiction. This means it has parts of novels and short stories. There are nice stories by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. 
Some less famous writers write about food. For example, Jane Harris wrote a story called Those Nails. Do not read it after eating. It has some very bad scenes that can make you feel sick! 
There are also poems from nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. Some writers share parts of their new novels, like Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. There is a little non-fiction too. Alan Rusbridger wrote a funny article about newspapers, and Ursula Owen wrote an interesting piece about herself. 
This is a great collection, and I am excited to see next year's book!'

Learning the Violin**
Margaret Porter is a violin teacher. She says the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. This is when children learn about the world. Margaret lives in London. She likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds.
Margaret started teaching the violin in 1972. Her first class had her children’s friends who were five years old. Her students learn in groups. Each group has about twelve students. They have lessons for one hour, every two weeks. Each student also has one lesson alone with her every week. 
Parents must come to the lessons. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons. In the first lessons, students learn to play music by ear. They do not read music for many years. At first, their playing is different from reading music. Margaret says her way of teaching is not to make great violinists. She tells students who play very well to study with other teachers.

Moonshine**
The band Moonshine has a new CD. It is called "Here Again." This is their third CD. The last CD was "The Waves." 
There are some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott plays the bass guitar now. He replaces Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer.
The first song on the CD is a dance song. The band will play more dance songs now, not just slow songs. The second song is also a dance song and is very loud. Many fans will be surprised by these songs. 
Rob Letchford is the singer. He sings very well. Fans are happy he recorded the songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. If you bought tickets, do not worry. The concerts will be rescheduled when Rob feels better.
On this CD, Moonshine shows they can play different types of music. Some songs are slow, and some are fast. I think the best songs are at the beginning. The last songs are not as good. 
"Here Again" will be a big hit and help the band become more successful.

San Francisco**
San Francisco is a city in northern California. A Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola found this area in 1769. San Francisco Bay is a beautiful place, but it was found by land, not by sea.
In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to find gold. But the people who got rich were not the gold seekers. The rich people owned banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill.
Today, many tourists visit San Francisco. They want to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some people take a boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

'SAMUEL PEPYS
Samuel Pepys wrote a famous diary in English. His diary talks about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important news, like sickness, a navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself. He says he sometimes slept in church and looked at pretty girls. 
He talks about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up. He was worried when she was sick. Pepys liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He had many important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

**The History of Shoes**
A long time ago, shoes were not very comfortable or stylish. People used animal skins to cover their feet. They tied these skins around their ankles when it was cold. 
Today, we still use leather for shoes, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton. This depends on what is popular.
One hundred and fifty years ago, people started to wear different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were the same shape and could be worn on either foot.
In the past, all shoes were made by hand. Now, many shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines help make many shoes quickly and at a lower price.

**Text:**
When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women enjoy running. I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers say there are not enough women in running, but they do not help by giving women places to change.
I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. Many wanted to lose weight, but they did not think about running before. They thought running was hard and painful. They did not know that running can be fun, with chatting and smiling in nice places, like by a river.
At first, they could only run for one minute. Now, they can run for thirty minutes! They also learned about healthy food and staying fit. I wanted to help women with running, and I am very happy to see how much they have improved.

**The History of the Iditarod - The Last Great Race on Earth**
In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the northern state of the USA. Many people came to find gold and get rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means "far place." In 1909, Iditarod became the largest city in Alaska for a short time.
In summer, boats brought supplies to the towns. But in winter, rivers and the ocean froze, and boats could not come. So, in 1910, people built a winter path for dog teams with sleds. They took mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at places called "roadhouses" to sleep and eat.
The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when planes replaced dog teams for transport. But in 1925, there was a disease called diphtheria in Nome. The medicine was in Anchorage, far away. Planes were new, and no one knew if they could fly in the cold. So, they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine.
The trip was over 1,000 kilometers along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to finish. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian, traveled the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo. Togo was very good at finding the way in the snow. The last part of the trip was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had worked with dog teams for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, stopped and saved the team from falling into icy water. The medicine arrived, and Balto became a hero.
Now, every year, there is a dog sled race from Anchorage to Nome. This race follows the famous journey from 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

Sweden's Ice Hotel**
The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Sweden. In winter, it can be very cold, up to -40 degrees Celsius. Many people, about 6,000, visit the Ice Hotel every year. This hotel is special because it is made of ice. You can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even have a wedding there!
The bar is made of ice too. It is not good to put hot drinks on the ice. The bedrooms are cold, about -4 degrees Celsius. But guests get warm sleeping bags to help them sleep. They can also get warm clothes if they need them.
The Ice Hotel is new every winter because it melts in summer. It takes a lot of ice and snow to build the hotel.

Maria Mutola**
In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on a boys' football team in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one cared that I was a girl. But then the other team was not happy." A local newspaper wrote about her story. Jose Craveirinha, who helped African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and saw her playing football. He knew she was very fast.
Jose talked to Maria about athletics. She did not understand. She only knew football. Then, he bought her running shoes and took her to train. It was hard work, and her legs hurt. Jose spoke to her parents and told them she could be successful. They agreed to let him help her train.
In 1991, Maria went to train in the United States. She was scared to go because she would miss her family. The girls in the US were different from her. They were good athletes, but Maria worried about food for her family. They worried about clothes and make-up. They did not know much about her life. But Maria felt lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and she learned a lot.
Today, Maria still runs. She lives happily in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.

**The Skywalk**
The Grand Canyon is in the United States. It was made by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk and run, but they mainly come to see the view. The view is very beautiful, and the Skywalk makes it even better. 
The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass. You can see the rocks of the canyon through the glass. Up to 120 people can stand on the Skywalk at the same time. It opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. 
When you walk on the Skywalk, you must wear special covers on your shoes. This is to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air.

**THE ROCKIES**
The Rocky Mountains are in North America. They start in the North-west and go down to the south. The Rockies are not as big as the Alps, but they are very beautiful. 
There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You can start your trip in Vancouver. Vancouver is a nice city in Canada. You can ski in the mountains just 15 minutes by car from the city.
Before, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to go across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week. The train ride is still very exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you see the beautiful views at night.

ZOOS**
People have kept animals in zoos for a long time. Over 3,000 years ago, the rulers of China made a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals did tricks for visitors, but now this does not happen. Now, zoos are for people to see animals living naturally.
Today, many cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people think zoos are good. They say zoos help us learn about animals and see them up close. 
But not everyone likes zoos. Some people think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and do not get good food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  
I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from other schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, and other bands wore bright T-shirts. We did not look like professional bands, but we played very well. Everyone was young, but we were good at playing music. Players from each band made new songs on stage. It was fun to watch, but it was even better when my band played!  
My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the people who want to play can be in the band. But anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We go on trips to jazz summer camps in different places. I have been to a few and learned a lot.  
Many adults are surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not hard enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can make your own music, but you also feel part of its history when you play on stage like great jazz musicians did before. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and parents who help us. Without them, we would not be able to do well in music!

Watering the Desert**
In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain from November to March. It does not rain often. When it rains, the streets can have a lot of water. This can make the streets look like rivers. The people in Marrakesh are happy when it rains because many winters are dry.
Marrakesh has parks and gardens. These do not get water from rain. They get water from underground channels. These channels were made a long time ago, in the 11th century. They bring water from the mountains all year.
Places that are mostly dry but have water from channels are called oases. 
If you go south from Marrakesh, you will find Skoura. In Skoura, people use all the land to grow food. There are water channels that help with this. The Atlas mountains, which have snow in winter, look beautiful in the background.

Gareth Ellis**
Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has two older brothers. They work in banking and computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown.
Three years ago, Gareth and his family joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it is true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath looked for jobs in the circus. They both found jobs, and Gareth started to train to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo.
In the summer, they travel with the circus. In the winter, they go home. Gareth's brothers take care of the house when they are away. Kath says, "It was not easy. We had to think about many things. We had a small car and a small caravan to sleep in. We left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long baths."
Gareth says, "People ask about my school. But wherever we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my friends at school, and I have a computer. I do not fall behind my classmates."
What about the future? Kath says, "It was a hard choice, but it is the best way to teach Gareth about being a clown. We are happy, and we enjoy it." Gareth says, "I want to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**
Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. You can join if you are between 8 and 18 years old. We collect news and write stories. We send these stories to newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. You can read or listen to the stories on the Eight-eighteen website.
We have three places in the country where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more places soon. Since we started in 1994, over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie is one of them. She says: "I heard about Eight-eighteen when they asked me about hip hop music. I met young journalists and saw what they did. Age did not matter. I went to the Eight-eighteen place in my city, got training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me a lot. I got a job at 19 and now I check articles for a big news website."
**Join Us!**
When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training. You will also have meetings every month to decide who will write each news story. Older members, called "peer trainers," help new members learn basic skills. Some of these trainers talk to groups of young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen. They always have support from older staff.
Eight-eighteen has training for new members three times a year. The next training is in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. You can join Eight-eighteen if you can read and write at any level. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**
Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.
In the summer, we take tourists on a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. The flight dates for next year are not ready yet, but if you book now, you can change your date if needed.
**Questions**
**How long is the flight?**  
The flight is about 12 hours. After about four hours, we see sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and then fly back home. During the flight, experts talk about Antarctica and answer questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.
**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and a seat at the end of the row for the other half. While over Antarctica, you can get up and move around the plane to see better. The pilot flies in big circles so everyone can see the sights.
**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans. The captain checks the weather on the morning of the flight and chooses the best way to see clearly.
**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife is far below the plane, so we cannot see them well. We do not land in Antarctica because of environmental reasons. To see wildlife, you need to go on a boat tour.
**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring your camera. We also have fun photo opportunities where you can wear cold weather clothes from Antarctica.

Little Chefs**
Some children, aged ten to fifteen, learn to cook on Saturdays. They have fun and make good food. Many children want to join the class, so there is a waiting list of 30 kids. Parents pay £280 for the course.
Bill is ten years old. He says, "I love my mum's cooking. Now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh when we eat the food we made."
Flora is twelve. She has trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby for the weekend. I was happy at home, so I did not want to go at first. But now I am glad I came."
Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It is fun. Children pay attention and remember better than adults. The kitchen is not always clean when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, the children can make food for themselves when they are older."

**Winter Driving**
Winter can be dangerous for driving. It is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be on the road, and ice can be under the snow. A car coming towards you can slide on the road.
**Rule Number One**: Drive smoothly. If you move the car too fast or too suddenly, it can be hard to control. When you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or go faster, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive so you do not spill it.
**Rule Number Two**: Pay attention to the road. Look far ahead, especially if there is ice. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. You may be driving faster than you think. 
When the road is wet, allow double the time to stop. On snow, allow three times the time. On ice, allow even more time. Try to keep control of your car, and you will be safe.

**Craigie Aitchison**
Craigie Aitchison is a painter. He was born in Scotland. He went to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. In art school, he found drawing hard, but he kept painting.
When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He liked early Italian artists, and this is seen in his paintings. He loved the green and brown fields in Italy and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted with thin layers of color, from light to dark. He said, "It's a secret - because I don't know what will happen." He does not start with a color and know what will come next.
Aitchison thinks painting is easy. He said, "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just see what colors look good together." He does not make drawings before he paints. He thinks if he draws first, he might get bored and not paint. He changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes to paint people who do not want to see their picture while he is painting. He said, "If they are worried and want to look, I can't paint."
Since he moved to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish art scene. He does not want to follow any tradition. He just paints in his own way. His work still inspires young British painters.

Rock Band**
Two years ago, our son Ben, who is 14 years old, asked us for drums for his birthday. At first, we did not want to buy them because of the noise. Ben said, "It is better than watching TV or playing computer games. It will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play."
After that, Ben's friends came to our house with their guitars and other music things. Now, our house is noisy with their music and singing for many hours each week. When they practice, my husband and I go for a long walk. 
Even if their music is a little strange, they are nice and polite. I do not know if they are good musicians, but they play at local clubs for young people. We worry that they will not do enough school work because of music, but this has not happened yet. I always tell Ben that his studies are very important. But one thing is sure: Ben was right. Playing music keeps him out of trouble and he is never bored.

Atlantic College**
Last week, I visited Atlantic College. It is a good private college in Wales. The college helps young people learn about life outside the classroom and study for their exams. 
The students are between 16 and 18 years old. They come from many countries. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities. They might help on a farm, care for people, or check rivers for pollution.
Atlantic College has students from different backgrounds. Many students cannot pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants to help them. About 25% of the students are British. Many British students get help from the government to attend.
Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I admire the college for helping young people understand each other. You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don’t like them. My mother said I argued less with my sister during the summer."
In short, Atlantic College gives students a great education with methods that work well.

Being an Older Student**
I am 32 years old. I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes and I read books. I also write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. 
Before, I worked as a secretary. I earned good money, but I was bored. I did not think much in my job. I felt sad because I thought I was stuck in that job. I saw students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to be like them.
Now, I am a student, but it is hard for me to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers. We are the same age, but I know less than they do.
I am happy to study because I need a qualification to get a good job. This is very important to me. I like to spend my weekends reading books instead of going to parties. I also enjoy the long holidays and discounts for the theatre and cinema.
Sometimes, I worry about what I will do after university. But I hope that going back to school now is a good choice.

Henry Ford**
Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen years old, he started to work as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. He drove it for 1,500 kilometers. Then, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong and light steel to make cars that were cheap for people to buy. 
In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T'. It cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but they had less choice. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it is black."

**Rebecca Stevens**
Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain, she was a journalist. She lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and traveled to Asia with some climbers. 
Life on Everest is hard. Rebecca said, "You must carry everything on your back. You can only take what you need. You can't wash on the mountain. I didn't even take a toothbrush. I am usually clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"
On May 17, 1993, Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest. It was the best moment of her life. She became famous. Now, she has written a book about her trip. People often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job on a science program on television. 
Rebecca is well known today. She has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.

"Dear Mike,

Love, Lorenzo"

CANADA GEESE**
Canada Geese are big birds. They are blue and white. In autumn, they fly south to find warm weather. It is very cold in Canada in winter. The birds can die if they stay there.
Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. The young birds lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds do not know what to do in autumn." 
Bill had a small plane. He decided to help the birds. All summer, he flew his plane, and the young geese followed him. 
When autumn came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States. Virginia is 600 miles south of Canada. The geese followed him all the way. 
Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the geese to come back. They did not come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks but could not find them. 
When Bill got home, he saw the geese waiting for him. They found their way home without him!

**Esther's Story**
Esther left school when she was sixteen years old. Her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used the money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon had £1,000.
At first, her parents did not want her to make jam. They wanted her to study and become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen. She kept making jam. After a few months, she sold it at the local market. Then she made orange juice and sold it to a school where her friend worked.
After two years, her business grew a lot. Her parents were very happy with her. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was very busy and needed to hire some people to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**
Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. Most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep. Each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool from the sheep. This helps the sheep not to be too warm.
Five years ago, Jenny made sweaters with the wool. She tried to sell them at markets, but it was summer and hot. People did not want to buy sweaters. So, she made socks instead. Everyone loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business started.
At first, Jenny made the socks at home. Soon, she had many customers. She had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are made on machines. There are six colors and five sizes for all ages. There are different socks for walking, sports, and skiing.
Jenny is very busy at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

'BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON'**
Many house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told us that house burglaries have gone up by more than 30% compared to last year. He said that 67% of burglaries happen when people go out and forget to close a door or a window. 
Night-time burglaries are not common because families are usually at home then. But winter afternoons are good for burglars because it is dark and they can’t be seen easily. Many houses are empty at this time because people are still at work.
Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch other houses when people are not home. They should call the police if they see something strange. 
Inspector Saunders said, "We will also tell you how to make your house safe. This help costs nothing."

**The History of Farming**
Before farming, people looked for plants and fruit in the forest to eat. They moved a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people started to grow food. These people were the first farmers. 
Farming helped people stay in one place. Their villages became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers grew food for everyone. 
Sometimes, farming was hard when the weather was bad. Some people did not have enough food to eat. 
Today, farmers grow more food. The food travels a long way to reach our homes.

WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**
Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen. She went to college and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she worked for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Later, she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she became a manager.
This is what she said about her job: "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend a lot of time in the air. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 
At work, the first thing I do is check plane times on my computer. Then, I talk with some air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. 
Travelling can be hard. When I come back from a long trip, I just want to eat and go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways. I want to stay there and keep traveling."

"The Weather People care about the weather. The weather is important for many jobs. For example, it is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to learn about the weather. Now, we have computers that help us understand the weather. People can also get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe old ideas about the weather. They say if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people think if cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon."

'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two boys who are 14 years old. They live in a small town in Canada. They are good friends and go to the same school. They like to go fishing and swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they have stayed in Peter's room. They are working on a computer game. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They made a new word game for computers. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin. Kevin has trouble with reading. He learns words better with pictures and sounds. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for many hours to make the game. Now it is ready to use. It is a game with pictures and sounds. Many schools want to buy it.'

HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE HEALTHILY?**
Sleeping well is very important. When I go home to my mother’s house, I sleep for ten hours. But after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my head is full of music. 
Sport is also important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now, I cannot do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups every day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I drink a lot of water because it is good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I do not always drink that much.
People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I like to do other things too. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. I do not feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!

Bollywood**
Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes about 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made more than 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, so it is the biggest film industry in the world. 
Many Indians like to watch films. Ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films often tell love stories, and there is a lot of singing and dancing in them. People outside India also enjoy Indian films. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling its films to other countries.
Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. Most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs more than $5 million to make. 
Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is a famous actor in India. He has been in more than 140 films and has acted for almost 40 years.

'Bill Bryson
I was born in the United States. I have written travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. Now, we live in the United States. Our children are learning about life here. I think they will be happy because they have lived in two countries.
I like England and I want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon. So, I will not go back for four years. I just went to England for six weeks. I worked on a radio show about the English language and talked about my new book. 
Most writers do not like to travel and sell their books. I do not mind it. I like to visit new places and meet people. It is very different from my life in the United States when I am writing. In England, people drove me in big cars and I stayed in nice hotels. It was good because I did not have to pay for anything. Everyone was nice to me and it was fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**
There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago. The Giant Schnauzer is bigger and has not been in England for a long time. The Giant Schnauzer is 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, and they need haircuts often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany. Farmers use these dogs to help with sheep. The police also use Schnauzers because they are very smart. Schnauzers are good family dogs. They are friendly and good with young children.

The Ruwenzori Mountains**
Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help make a road through a forest.
Mary said, "It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food." It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. The Ruwenzori Mountains are one of the wettest places in the world.
Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She wants to go back next year to help again.

The History of Horse Racing**
Horse racing is an important sport. It started a long time ago, about 4,500 years ago, in Central Asia. People in Greece and Rome liked horse racing too. 
Modern horse racing began in Europe in the 12th century when Arab horses came to Europe. At first, there were long races with only two horses. But in the 18th century, races became shorter and had many horses. 
Today, many people watch horse racing in the USA. It is very popular, second only to baseball. Horse racing is also popular in other parts of the world.

'Nick Barlow is a world traveller. He is a British actor. He travels to many countries to make TV shows. "People are nice to me everywhere," he says. "When I go home, I remember all the good things from each country." 
Nick has been to many places, but he wants to visit South America and go back to Australia one day. He travels with a team. They bring cameras and other things to make the show. Nick takes a few shirts and trousers, but he always brings books in his suitcase.
Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him travelling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick comes home, she likes to hear his travel stories. 
Sometimes, there are problems. When Nick was in the Malaysian rain forest, he heard that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt bad because I could not help her, but she did not want me to come home. I was very happy when I heard she was better."

Parrots**
Parrots are beautiful birds. They have nice colors and long tails. You can see them in the forest or in the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They like to live in big groups. Parrots eat fruit, and sometimes they can be a problem for farmers.
There are many types of parrots. All parrots have strong beaks and feet. They use their beaks and feet to climb and hold food. Some parrots can live for 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart. You can teach them to talk. Some zoos have shows with parrots. You can see the parrots do tricks they have learned.

'HOWARD BONNIER
Bray is a nice village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young man named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know his name yet, but he is famous in France. He has written about many good restaurants in French magazines. He is 29 years old.
When Howard was a teenager, he went to restaurants with his parents. He liked this a lot. He decided to spend his money on visiting France and eating in good restaurants instead of buying clothes and CDs. He also has many cookbooks. He says he has more than two hundred and fifty!
Why did he open a restaurant? He loves cooking. Is it easy? He says it is expensive to start a restaurant. It is harder to cook for fifty people than for his family, but he thinks he did the right thing.'

John Pickering**
In a small park in England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers. Last week, he was in Tokyo, Japan. Many people in Japan watched him on television because he is a famous singer there. 
John went to Japan a few months ago to sing in clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the DJ to ask for his songs again. 
John sings under the name Jon Otis in Japan. He still works in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from singing. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I need to pay my bills!" 
The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, "This will not change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Line Dancing**
Many people in Britain have a new hobby: line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for this fun activity. 
"Line dancing is easy to learn," says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "If you can walk, you can do it!" You do not need a partner because you dance in groups. It is a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are young and old people. The boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet when they dance!
When did line dancing start? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**
There are five types of rhinos in the world. The Black and White rhinos live in Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. Rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is hard and they have little hair. Rhinos stand on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They walk slowly, but they can run fast, up to 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are quiet and calm. They eat grass and plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays in its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs more than 200 kilos and can live for 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**
A long time ago, in 1700, there were no policemen in London. Only a few old men helped to protect the streets at night, and they did not get paid much. 
London was getting bigger, but it was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money, so people stayed at home. 
In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding paid some people to stop the thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. 
Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force started with 3000 officers. Most of the men walked, but some rode horses. 
Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police get paid well, and the few police officers who ride horses get paid even more.

'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people go to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, for the Edinburgh Festival. This festival is in August and September and lasts for three weeks. The city has many actors and artists from different countries. The streets are full of music and dance from morning to night. You can see artists painting pictures on the streets. 
One fun part of the Festival is the 'Fringe'. Here, students do funny shows in small places like cafes. Many tourists come to see new films, plays, and listen to famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred shows with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets are not very expensive, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. 
So, come to Edinburgh next summer! But remember, it can be hard to find a room, so it is a good idea to book your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**
If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will find Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake is covered with ice. Many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. They sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice.
Bob Marvisch has come here for twenty-five years. He says, "You need light but warm clothes: two pairs of socks, gloves, thin sweaters, and a snow suit." 
Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small hole. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. When the fish eat the bread, you pull the line up. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but Bob prefers chocolate or snacks after he catches three or four fish. 
Today, he has caught twenty-five fish! It is a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here!

Madame Tussaud's**
Madame Tussaud's is a famous place for tourists in London. It is a museum. In this museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. 
Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor. He made wax figures of people and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped her uncle.
In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie went to prison. In prison, she had to make wax heads of famous people who were dead, like Queen Marie Antoinette.
In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she came to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum in London. You can still see her figures today.

**BICYCLES**
A bicycle is a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive. Only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from today’s bicycles. Later, bicycles became cheaper, and many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and for fun. 
Today, many people use cars more than bicycles. Cars are faster, and you don’t get wet when it rains! But some people still like to ride bicycles to work. They say there are too many cars in town, and it is hard to find a place to park!

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14
Last summer, I went to Thailand with my family. We had a beach holiday. One day, we went to a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flowers, but we wanted to see the elephant show. 
We went to a big square with seats. Three elephants came in with their keepers. They stood in front of a big white card. Each elephant had a paintbrush. They started to paint on the card. The keepers gave them new brushes with paint and took the old ones away. 
The elephants painted pictures. One picture was of a river, one was of a tree, and one was of flowers. When the keepers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants bananas that we brought for lunch. 
Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there. The smartest elephants live in special places where people can watch them.

Big Cats**
There are many kinds of cats. They are different in size and look. Tigers are the biggest cats. They can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats do not like water, but tigers like to lie in water when it is hot. 
Lions are the only cats that live in big family groups. Many lions work together to find food. They usually live in flat, open places where they can see far and follow other animals. 
All cats need good eyes to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

**THE OSTRICH**
The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. 
Ostriches can run very fast, up to 90 kilometres an hour. This makes it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens. They take about 3 years to grow up. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.

'Victoria Jamieson is a snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now, she is 23 and has won many competitions. We talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland last week. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I like sports, especially skiing. It was easy to start snowboarding. You can learn quickly and get good in a few months." 
We asked her if she practices a lot. She said, "In winter, I snowboard every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love it! I like competitions and being in the mountains. It is very beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding for fun, is the best for me." 
We asked her what is important when learning. She said, "You can learn fast, but you need lessons. It is also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet because you will fall a lot at first!"'

Mount Kilimanjaro**
Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people climb Kilimanjaro. Some are very young, like a seven-year-old boy, and some are old, like an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and many tourists like it. 
Only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro reach the top. This can happen because the weather changes quickly. At the start, it can be hot and rainy. But at the top, there is ice and snow, and it can be very cold, below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring sunglasses and warm clothes!

Otters**
Not many people have seen an otter. Otters live near rivers. They make their homes from small pieces of wood. Otters usually come out at night. They are very good swimmers and can swim fast. Otters have thick brown fur. This keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose. This helps them stay under water for a long time.
Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were dirty, and many fish and insects died. Otters could not find food. But now, the rivers are clean, and there is a lot of food for otters.

Buildings**
People have always made buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We have museums to keep beautiful things.
Many people work together on a building. The architect decides how the building looks and draws pictures of it. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers build it carefully.
The Sydney Opera House is a famous building. It has a beautiful roof. The building is nice to see from all sides, not just the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich is also famous. It looks like a tent made of glass.
