'The Cerne Giant
Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one hill, there is a picture of a very big man. This man is called the Cerne Giant. The village next to him is called Cerne. 
We do not know when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on May 1st when the sun comes up, you will see many people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Gail Rollins**
Gail Rollins is a great runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run 10,000 metres and maybe 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail often came second in big races. She always smiled, and people in her city love her for this.
In 2004, Gail ran her first half-marathon, which is a long race. She won and had the best time of the year for British women runners. Her husband, Mike Rollins, was also a runner when he was younger. But he hurt his right leg and cannot run in races now. He can run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. It is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him.
Gail trains hard. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. She rests from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should eat that?' It is usually cake, but she can eat almost everything."

Piano Players - When They Were Young**
**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. When he was twelve, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano, but she taught him and his sister songs. His mother taught him to play the piano when he was six. At ten, he wanted to write music. He started his first song.
**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father taught him some Russian music. At six, he had lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg won prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Then, he came back to Russia.
**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German. He taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two. A year later, he started playing the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he gave fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef liked music, but he also liked physics and languages. He is busy now, but one day he wants to write his own music.

Bill Prince-Smith**
Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist. He became a writer of children's books when he was 60 years old. Now, he is 73 and has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me if she does not like something," says Bill. 
Bill has ten grandchildren. They do not live near him, but they read his stories and tell him if they are good or bad. This helps Bill know what children like to read. 
Bill writes about life in his village and on the farms nearby. His favorite book is called *The Sheepdog*. It is about a farmer and his dog. "I have always liked animals," says Bill. "Dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." 
Last year, they made a film of his book with real animals and actors. The film-makers used computers to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes film-makers change books, but they did not change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**
Today, people send postcards to friends and family. Postcards have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday. Postcards are cheap, and the pictures are often nice.
The first postcard was sent a long time ago, at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed news, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these postcards because they did not have pictures in their newspapers.

Dinosaurs**
No one has seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago. This was a long time before people were on Earth. We do not know why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. 
Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest dinosaurs were larger than any other animals that lived on land. 
For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long. It ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat. It could run fast because it had long back legs.

**Bears**
Bears are big animals. They can be dangerous. An adult bear is very strong and can hurt a person. Bears can climb trees and run fast. But they do not see well. They find food with their noses.
There are seven types of bears. The biggest bear is the white polar bear. It is almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears. One lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black. They can be dark brown or reddish brown.
Many people love the black and white panda bear. The panda comes from China. There are not many pandas in the forest today because it is hard for them to find food.

**CROCODILES**
Crocodiles live in warm places like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They like to stay in slow water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You can see many crocodiles together in groups. They eat fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they eat big animals or even people.
There are more than ten kinds of crocodiles. They have very sharp teeth. They can lose their teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some are bigger. They can live a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**
In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon. This balloon took people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers made the first plane with an engine. They flew in this plane in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 
Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world. It can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour. The trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 
Today, many people travel by aeroplane. It is hard to think of a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**
The Globe Theatre is in London. It is very old. It was built 400 years ago. The theatre was round and had no roof. If it rained, people got wet and cold. 
The queen liked to go to the Globe Theatre. She watched plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. 
People who visited the theatre ate food, talked to friends, and walked around during the show. Some people even threw things at the actors!
Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place by the River Thames. You can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life 400 years ago.
